posts.title: The Codex App
posts.author: meetpateltech
posts.title_cn: "法典应用"
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕OpenAI新发布的Codex应用展开。核心话题聚焦于AI辅助编程工具的实际表现、技术实现方式及其市场定位。社区观点呈现明显分歧：部分用户对Codex的编程能力表示赞赏，认为其虽然存在错误但整体表现令人惊喜；也有用户严厉批评其反应迟钝、逻辑混乱且经常无视指令，甚至引发使用者的愤怒情绪。技术层面存在争议，有用户指出其基于Electron框架开发并质疑AI巨头为何不开发真正原生应用，但随即有反驳观点认为Electron完全能调用原生API，争论本质在于UI实现策略。产品策略方面，多位用户批评其仅支持Mac平台的做法显示出开发团队与主流市场的脱节。讨论中还提到该应用与Claude等竞品的相似性，以及其短期免费策略可能对编程代理市场产生的影响。整体而言，社区对AI编程工具的实际效用和技术路线尚未形成共识。

comments.author: OlympicMarmoto
comments.content: It is baffling how these AI companies, with billions of dollars, cannot build native applications, even with the help of AI. From a UI perspective, these are mostly just chat apps, which are not particularly difficult to code from scratch. Before the usual excuses come about how it is impossible to build a custom UI, consider software that is orders of magnitude more complex, such as raddbg, 10x, Superluminal, Blender, Godot, Unity, and UE5, or any video game with a UI. On top of that, programs like Claude Cowork or Codex should, by design, integrate as deeply with the OS as possible. This requires calling native APIs (e.g., Win32), which is not feasible from Electron.
comments.content_cn: 令人费解的是，这些拥有数十亿美元资金的AI公司，即便借助AI之力，竟也无法开发出原生应用程序。从用户界面角度看，这些大多只是聊天应用，从头开始编写代码并非特别困难。在那些关于构建定制界面如何不可能的惯常托辞出现之前，不妨想想那些复杂程度高出几个数量级的软件——比如raddbg、10x、Superluminal、Blender、Godot、Unity、UE5，或是任何带有用户界面的电子游戏。更重要的是，像Claude Cowork或Codex这类程序，其设计本应尽可能深度集成操作系统。这需要调用原生API（例如Win32），而这在Electron框架下是无法实现的。

comments.author: ttul
comments.content: I had been procrastinating putting in the effort to find a decent web designer to redesign our company’s website because I couldn’t stomach the hours I would need to put in to educate them about our messaging and to slowly go around and around iteratively to get the design nailed.Last week, I decided to try building the site myself using Codex (the terminal one). I chose Astro as the framework because I wanted to learn about it. I fed it some marketing framework materials (positioning statements and whatnot) and showed it some website designs that we like. I then asked it to produce a first cut and it one-shotted a pretty decent bit of output.AGI is definitely a few more years away, because I’ve since invested probably 30 hours of iteration to make the site into something that is closer to what I eventually want to launch. But here’s the thing: I never intended for Codex to produce THE final website. But now I’m thinking, “maybe we can?” On my team, we have just enough expertise and design know-how to at least know what looks good and we are developers so we definitely know what good code looks like. And Codex is nailing it on both those fronts.As I said, we’re far from AGI. There’s no way I can one-shot something like this. It requires iteration with humans who have years of “context” built up. But maybe the days of hiring a designer and just praying that they somehow get it right are behind us.
comments.content_cn:
我一直在拖延寻找合适的网页设计师来重新设计公司网站，因为想到要花费大量时间向他们解释我们的品牌理念，并反复进行迭代修改才能敲定设计，就让我感到难以承受。上周我决定尝试用Codex（终端版）自己建站。选择Astro作为框架是因为我想学习这个技术。我给它输入了一些营销框架材料（定位声明等），并展示了我们喜欢的网站设计范例。当我要求它生成初版设计时，它一次性就输出了相当不错的成果。

通用人工智能确实还需要数年时间才能实现，因为后来我花了大约30个小时进行迭代修改，才让网站更接近最终想发布的效果。但关键在于：我原本根本没指望Codex能直接生成最终版网站。现在我却开始思考“或许真的可以？”在我们团队里，我们具备足够的设计专业知识和判断力，至少能辨别美观与否，而且作为开发者，我们当然清楚优质代码的标准。而Codex在这两方面都表现出色。

正如我所说，我们距离通用人工智能还很遥远。我不可能一次性就获得完美成果，这需要与具备多年行业“背景知识”的人类进行迭代合作。但或许，那种雇佣设计师后只能祈祷他们恰好理解需求的日子已经过去了。

comments.author: nr378
comments.content: Looks like another Claude App/Cowork-type competitor with slightly different tradeoffs (Cowork just calls Claude Code in a VM, this just calls Codex CLI with OS sandboxing).Here's the Codex tech stack in case anyone was interested like me.Framework: Electron 40.0.0Frontend:- React 19.2.0- Jotai (state management)- TanStack React Form- Vite (bundler)- TypeScriptBackend/Main Process:- Node.js- better-sqlite3 (local database)- node-pty (terminal emulation)- Zod (validation)- Immer (immutable state)Build & Dev:- pnpm (package manager)- Electron Forge- Vitest (testing)- ESLint + PrettierNative/macOS:- Sparkle (auto-updates)- Squirrel (installer)- electron-liquid-glass (macOS vibrancy effects)- Sentry (error tracking)
comments.content_cn:
看起来又是一个类似Claude App/Cowork的竞品，只是在权衡取舍上略有不同（Cowork只是在虚拟机中调用Claude Code，而这个是通过操作系统沙箱调用Codex CLI）。以下是Codex的技术栈，供像我一样感兴趣的人参考。

框架：Electron 40.0.0
前端：
- React 19.2.0
- Jotai（状态管理）
- TanStack React Form
- Vite（打包工具）
- TypeScript
后端/主进程：
- Node.js
- better-sqlite3（本地数据库）
- node-pty（终端模拟）
- Zod（验证）
- Immer（不可变状态）
构建与开发：
- pnpm（包管理器）
- Electron Forge
- Vitest（测试）
- ESLint + Prettier
原生/macOS：
- Sparkle（自动更新）
- Squirrel（安装程序）
- electron-liquid-glass（macOS透明效果）
- Sentry（错误追踪）

comments.author: jtrn
comments.content: People's mileage may vary, but in my instance, this was so bad that I actually got angry while trying to use it.It's slow and stupid. It does not do proper research. It does not follow instructions. It randomly decides to stop being agentic, and instead just dumps the code for me to paste. It has the extremely annoying habit of just doing stuff without understanding what I meant, making a mess, then claiming everything is fine. The outdated training data is extremely annoying when working with Nuxt 4+. It is not creative at solving problems. It dosent show the thinking. The Undo code does not give proper feedback on the diff and if it actually did "undo." And I hate the personality. It HAS to be better than it comes off for me because I am actually in a bad mood after having worked with it. I would rather YOLO code with Gemini 3 flash, since it's actually smarter in my assessment, and at least I can iterate faster, and it feels like it has better common sense.Just as an example, I found an old, terrible app I made years ago for our firm that handles room reservations. I told it to update from Bootstrap to Flowbite UI. Codex just took forever to make a mess, installed version 2.7 when 4.0.1 is the latest, even when I explicitly stated that it should use the absolute latest version. Then it tried to install it and failed, so it reverted to the outdated CDN.I gave the same task to Claude Code. Same prompt. It one-shotted it quickly. Then I asked it to swap out ALL the fetch logic to have SPA-like functionality with the new beta 4 version of HTMX, and it one-shot that too in the time Codex spent just trying to read a few files in the project.This reminds me of the feeling I had when I got the Nokia N800. It was so promising on paper, but the product was so bad and terrible to use that I knew Nokia was done for. If this was their take on what an acceptable smartphone could be, it proves that the whole foundation is doomed. If this is OpenAI's take on what an agentic coding assistant should be—something that can run by itself and iterate until it completes its task in an intelligent and creative way.... OpenAI is doomed.
comments.content_cn:
每个人的体验可能不同，但就我而言，这款产品糟糕到让我在使用过程中感到愤怒。它反应迟钝且愚笨，无法进行有效检索，也不遵循操作指令。它会突然停止自主处理，转而直接抛出一堆代码让我粘贴。最令人恼火的是，它总在未理解我意图的情况下擅自操作，把事情搞得一团糟后还声称一切正常。在处理Nuxt 4+项目时，其过时的训练数据尤其令人头疼。它缺乏解决问题的创造力，从不展示思考过程。代码撤销功能既不显示差异对比，也不反馈是否真正执行了“撤销”操作。我甚至讨厌它的交互个性。按理说它应该表现得更好才对，因为实际使用后我的心情确实变差了。相比之下，我宁愿用Gemini 3 flash进行快速编码——在我看来它更智能，至少能让我更快地迭代，而且似乎具备更好的常识判断力。

comments.author: gloosx
comments.content: >This requires calling native APIs (e.g., Win32), which is not feasible from Electron.Who told you that? You can write entire C libraries and call them from Electron just fine. Browser is a native application after all. All this "native applications" debate boils down to the UI implementation strategy. Maintaining three separate UI stacks (WinUI, SwiftUI, GTK/Qt) is dramatically more expensive and slower to iterate on than a single web-based UI with shared logicWe already have three major OSes, all doing things differently. The browsers, on the other hand, use the same language, same rendering model, same layout system, and same accessibility layer everywhere, which is a massive abstraction win.You don't casually give up massive abstraction wins just to say "it's native". If "just build it natively" were actually easier, faster, or cheaper at scale, everyone would do just that.
comments.content_cn: 这需要调用原生API（例如Win32），而Electron无法实现这种操作。谁告诉你的？你完全可以编写完整的C语言库并从Electron中顺利调用。毕竟浏览器本身就是原生应用程序。所有关于“原生应用”的争论归根结底是UI实现策略的问题。维护三套独立的UI框架（WinUI、SwiftUI、GTK/Qt）的成本极高，迭代速度也远低于采用共享逻辑的单一网页化UI方案。我们早已面对三大主流操作系统，它们各自采用不同的实现方式。而浏览器则在不同平台上使用相同的语言、相同的渲染模型、相同的布局系统和相同的无障碍访问层——这是抽象层设计的重大胜利。没有人会轻易放弃这种巨大的抽象优势，仅仅为了标榜“这是原生应用”。如果“直接开发原生应用”真的在大规模开发中更简单、更快速或更经济，所有人早就采用这种方式了。

comments.author: dworks
comments.content: Somewhat underwhelmed. I consider agents to be a sidetrack. The key insight from the Recursive Language Models paper is that requirements, implementation plans, and other types of core information should not be part of context but exist as immutable objects that can be referenced as a source of truth. In practice this just means creating an .md file per stage (spec, analysis, implementation plan, implementation summary, verification and test plan, manual qa plan, global state reference doc).I created this using PLANS.md and it basically replicates a kanban/scrum process with gated approvals per stage, locked artifacts when it moves to next stage, etc. It works very well and it doesnt need a UI. Sure, I could have several agents running at the same time, but I believe manual QA is key to keeping the codebase clean, so time spent on this today means that future requirements can be implemented 10x faster than with a messy codebase.
comments.content_cn: 有些失望。我认为智能代理是个岔路。《递归语言模型》论文的核心洞见在于：需求、实施方案等核心信息不应作为上下文的一部分，而应作为可被引用的不可变对象存在，作为事实依据。实践中，这意味着为每个阶段创建独立的.md文件（规格说明、分析、实施计划、实施总结、验证测试计划、手动测试方案、全局状态参考文档）。我通过PLANS.md实现了这套流程，本质上复现了看板/Scrum的工作模式——每个阶段设有审批关卡，进入下一阶段后产出物即被锁定等。这套系统运行良好且无需用户界面。当然，我可以同时运行多个智能代理，但我坚信人工测试是保持代码库整洁的关键。如今在这方面投入时间，意味着未来实现新需求的速度将比面对混乱代码库时快十倍。

comments.author: dworks
comments.content: The stages are modelled after a kanban board. So you can have whichever stages you think are important for your LLM development workflow. These are mine:00: Iterate on requirements with ChatGPT outside of the IDE. Save as a markdown requirements doc in the repo01: Inside the IDE; Analysis of current codebase based on the scope of the requirements02: Based on 00 and 01, write the implementation plan. Implement the plan03: Verification of implementation coverage and testing04: Implementation summary05: Manual QA based on generated doc06: Update global STATE.md and DECISIONS.md that documents the app, and the what and why of every requirementEvery stage has a single .md as output and after the stage is finished the doc is locked. Every stage takes the previous stages' docs as input.I have a half-finished draft with more details and a benchmark (need to re-run it since a missing dependency interrupted the runs)https://dilemmaworks.com/implementing-recursive-language-mod...
comments.content_cn:
阶段设计参考了看板方法。你可以根据自己LLM开发流程的需要设置任意阶段。以下是我的阶段划分：
00：在IDE外使用ChatGPT迭代需求。将需求文档保存为Markdown格式存入代码库
01：在IDE内；基于需求范围分析现有代码库
02：基于00和01阶段成果，编写实施方案并执行
03：验证实现覆盖率和测试
04：生成实施总结
05：基于生成的文档进行人工质量检查
06：更新记录应用程序的全局STATE.md和DECISIONS.md文件，说明每个需求的内容及原因

每个阶段都会生成单个.md文件作为输出，阶段完成后文档即被锁定。每个阶段都将前一阶段的文档作为输入。

我有一份包含更多细节和基准测试的半成品草案（由于缺少依赖项中断了运行，需要重新执行测试）
https://dilemmaworks.com/implementing-recursive-language-mod...

comments.author: markbao
comments.content: TUI is easy to train on, but hard to use for users. Part of the reason it’s easier to have LLMs use a bunch of Unix tools for us is that their text interface is tedious and hard to remember. If you’re a top 5% expert in those tools it doesn’t matter as much I guess but most people aren’t.Even a full-featured TUI like Claude Code is highly limited compared to a visual UI. Conversation branching, selectively applying edits, flipping between files, all are things visual UI does fine that are extremely tedious in TUI.Overall it comes down to the fact that people have to use TUI and that’s more important than it being easy to train, and there’s a reason we use websites and not terminals for rich applications these days.
comments.content_cn: TUI易于训练，但用户使用起来却很困难。部分原因在于，让大型语言模型为我们使用一堆Unix工具之所以更容易，是因为它们的文本界面既繁琐又难以记忆。如果你是对这些工具掌握程度在前5%的专家，这可能不那么重要，但大多数人并非如此。即使是像Claude Code这样功能齐全的TUI，与可视化界面相比也极为受限。对话分支、选择性应用编辑、在文件间切换——所有这些在可视化界面中都能轻松完成，而在TUI中却极其繁琐。归根结底，关键在于人们必须使用TUI，这比它易于训练更为重要，这也是如今我们使用网站而非终端来运行丰富应用程序的原因。

comments.author: dudeinhawaii
comments.content: Curious, are you doing the same planning with Codex out-of-band or otherwise? In order to have the same measurable outcome you'd need to perhaps use Codex in a plan state (there's experimental settings - not recommended) or other means (explicit detailed -reusable- prompt for planning a change). It's a missing feature if your preference is planning in CLI (I do not prefer this).You are correct in that this mode isn't "out of the box" as it is with Claude (but I don't use it in Claude either).My preference is to have smart models generate a plan with provided source. I wrote (with AI) a simple python tool that'll filter a codebase and let me select all files or just a subset. I then attach that as context and have a smart model with large context (usually Opus, GPT-5.2, and Gemini 3 Pro in parallel), give me their version of a plan. I then take the best parts of each plan, slap it into a single markdown and have Codex execute in a phased manner. I usually specify that the plan should be phased.I prefer out-of-CLI planning because frankly it doesn't matter how good Codex or Claude Code dive in, they always miss something unless they read every single file and config. And if they do that, they tip over. Doing it out of band with specialized tools, I can ensure they give me a high quality plan that aligns with the code and expectations, in a single shot (much faster).Then Claude/Codex/Gemini implement the phased plan - either all at once - or stepwise with me testing the app at each stage.But yeah, it's not a skill issue on your part if you're used to Plan -> Implement within Claude Code. The Experimental /collab feature does this but it's not supported and more experimental than even the experimental settings.
comments.content_cn:
好奇问一下，你们是否也在用Codex进行类似的离线规划或其他方式？为了达到相同的可衡量结果，你可能需要在计划状态下使用Codex（有实验性设置——但不推荐）或其他方法（使用明确详细且可重复的提示来规划变更）。如果你偏好通过CLI进行规划（我个人不倾向这种方式），这确实是一个缺失的功能。你说得对，这种模式不像Claude那样“开箱即用”（不过我在Claude里也不用这个功能）。

我更喜欢让智能模型根据提供的源代码生成计划。我（借助AI）编写了一个简单的Python工具，可以筛选代码库并让我选择全部文件或部分子集。然后我将这些作为上下文附加，并让具有大上下文的智能模型（通常是并行使用Opus、GPT-5.2和Gemini 3 Pro）给出它们版本的计划。接着我提取每个计划的精华部分，整合成一份Markdown文档，并让Codex分阶段执行。我通常会要求计划必须分阶段进行。

我倾向于在CLI之外进行规划，因为坦白说，无论Codex或Claude Code的代码潜入功能多强大，除非它们读取每一个文件和配置，否则总会遗漏某些内容。而如果真这么做，它们又会不堪重负。通过使用专门工具进行离线处理，我能确保它们一次性生成与代码和预期相符的高质量计划（这要快得多）。

然后由Claude/Codex/Gemini实施分阶段计划——要么一次性完成，要么逐步推进，由我在应用测试过程中……

posts.title: France dumps Zoom and Teams as Europe seeks digital autonomy from the US
posts.author: AareyBaba
posts.title_cn: 法国弃用Zoom和Teams，欧洲寻求数字自主摆脱美国依赖
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕法国政府弃用Zoom和Teams、推动数字自主的举措展开。核心话题是欧洲寻求减少对美国科技依赖的尝试，法国自主开发并开源替代软件（MIT许可）成为焦点。

社区观点多元：有人认为欧洲过度依赖美国软件存在政治风险，美国法律可能迫使企业配合政府，因此数字自主至关重要；也有用户指出此举目前仅限政府层面，普通民众仍依赖美国科技。讨论中提到法国采用的软件栈（如Django+React）及部分开源产品（如Grist），体现了技术落地的复杂性。

分歧点在于成效评估：部分用户积极评价开源替代方向，认为欧盟市场潜力巨大；但另有观点强调，欧盟缺乏本土大型科技公司，全面脱离美国生态仍面临挑战。共识在于对美国软件体验的不满，多位用户批评Teams等工具难用，间接支持替代尝试。

命名争议也被提及：新软件“Visio”与微软产品重名，可能造成混淆。整体上，讨论既肯定数字自主的意义，也对其实际效果持审慎态度。

Spain and Italy lag behind but sometimes, surprisingly, also do the right thing. The real troublemaker is ... Germany. For a reason nobody understands, Germany is like an US satellite in everything it does, but only ... half-hearted. Naturally, "the economy" is one reason (export centric country so it is readily blackmailable by the USA here) but even then you have to ask why german politicians have absolutely no pride at all. 法国有些方面做得不错；斯堪的纳维亚国家也是（我在此将荷兰纳入考量，虽然他们不属斯堪的纳维亚，但其决策模式常像是法国与丹麦/瑞典的混合体）。西班牙和意大利相对滞后，但偶尔也会出人意料地采取正确行动。真正的麻烦制造者是……德国。出于无人理解的原因，德国在所有事务上都像美国的卫星国，却又总是……半心半意。当然“经济因素”是原因之一（出口导向型国家易受美国要挟），但即便如此仍要追问：为何德国政客毫无自尊？法国人有自尊——这既是优点也是缺点，但在当前语境下是优势。（英国脱欧后实质上更像是美国殖民地，随着法拉奇可能胜选——并将造成更多损害。英国人始终未能吸取教训。）

posts.title_cn: 法国X办公室遭突袭，英国对Grok展开新调查
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕X公司在法国办公室被搜查及英国对Grok展开新调查的事件展开。核心话题是执法行动的实际意义与动机。有用户质疑“搜查”科技公司办公室的具体含义，认为数字时代应更关注源代码或通信记录等电子证据。也有用户指出这可能涉及法国特定的合规要求，或是收购前遗留的结构问题。讨论中提到部分用户将此事与马斯克的其他争议关联，暗示其个人行为可能影响公司处境。同时，有观点强调搜查本质是依法进行的执法程序，媒体使用“突袭”一词可能误导公众。分歧在于对调查必要性的看法：有人认为此举可能针对潜在非法内容，也有用户讽刺执法效率，质疑能否找到实质证据。普遍共识是此类调查可能对X及关联企业的公众形象与商业活动产生负面影响。

posts.title: Qwen3-Coder-Next
posts.author: danielhanchen
posts.title_cn: Qwen3-Coder-Next
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Qwen3-Coder-Next模型展开，核心话题是评估这款开源代码生成模型的实际性能与应用前景。多数用户对其在有限资源下的表现表示肯定，认为它在本地运行效率上具有优势。有人认为该模型在笔记本电脑上能以较低计算成本提供实用的编程辅助，适合脚本和小型项目；也有用户指出，尽管其声称性能接近顶级模型，但在实际测试中仍略逊于规模更大的模型如MiniMax M2.1。讨论中提到，部分用户通过工具如llama.cpp成功在本地部署，并分享了配置经验。争议点主要集中在模型与闭源商业产品的差距：有用户认为本地模型仍远不及付费产品实用，且推理速度较慢；但另一方指出，结合智能编排工具，轻量模型可能整体效率更高。此外，有评论延伸至该模型在全球南方市场的战略意义。共识在于，该模型在轻量化与性能平衡上表现突出，为本地开发提供了可行选择，但速度和能力尚未完全满足高端需求。

comments.author: SamDc73
comments.content: This is model 12188, which claims to rival SOTA models while not even being in the same league.In terms of intelligence per compute, it’s probably the best model I can realistically run locally on my laptop for coding. It’s solid for scripting and small projects.I tried it on a mid-size codebase (~50k LOC), and the context window filled up almost immediately, making it basically unusable unless you’re extremely explicit about which files to touch. I tested it with a 8k context window but will try again with 32k and see if it becomes more practical.I think the main blocker for using local coding models more is the context window. A lot of work is going into making small models “smarter,” but for agentic coding that only gets you so far. No matter how smart the model is, an agent will blow through the context as soon as it reads a handful of files.

comments.content_cn:
我们需要一个新术语，不是“本地模型”而是“基于资本支出的‘我的个人计算机模型’”。这个区分很重要，因为某些声称“支持本地模型”的工具实际上采用了类似ollama编排的方式，或是通过llama.cpp库连接同一台物理机上的模型。这不符合我对“本地”的定义。我指的是“本地网络”。所以在想出更好的说法前，可以称之为“局域网模型”。“自托管”这个概念虽然存在，但通常更偏向“开放权重”的含义，而非限制模型性能。

应当将其定义为成本约低于1万美元（采用史蒂夫·乔布斯的百万分美元计量单位）。本质上是通过硬件所需投入的“百万分美元”数值来分类，确保机器运行时不出现内存溢出。这就是我所说的“本地”：在我控制的、至多数千美元的硬件上“免费”运行推理任务。如果追求更高配置，甚至可能实现以天为单位的微调。

一套搭载线程撕裂者处理器、NVMe硬盘、256GB内存的现代5090配置大约需要1万美元（误差±1000美元）。而采用MLX方案的税后成本约为6000美元（m3-ultra 60核配256GB内存）。

最后需要强调的是，不能仅看“参数量”。并非所有32B Q4_K_M模型都以相同速率加载或占用相同内存。内部架构至关重要，随着前沿技术革新，激活参数量+量化程度的衡量方式正逐渐失去参考价值。

或许我们需要建立标准化评估基准：针对标准硬件等级，通过工具调用、代码生成等基础现实任务进行测试……

comments.author: openclawai
comments.content: For context on what cloud API costs look like when running coding agents:With Claude Sonnet at $3/$15 per 1M tokens, a typical agent loop with ~2K input tokens and ~500 output per call, 5 LLM calls per task, and 20% retry overhead (common with tool use): you're looking at roughly $0.05-0.10 per agent task.At 1K tasks/day that's ~$1.5K-3K/month in API spend.The retry overhead is where the real costs hide. Most cost comparisons assume perfect execution, but tool-calling agents fail parsing, need validation retries, etc. I've seen retry rates push effective costs 40-60% above baseline projections.Local models trading 50x slower inference for $0 marginal cost start looking very attractive for high-volume, latency-tolerant workloads.
comments.content_cn: 关于运行代码代理时云端API成本的背景说明：以Claude Sonnet每百万token收费3/15美元为例，典型代理循环每次调用约需2000输入token和500输出token，每个任务进行5次LLM调用，加上工具使用中常见的20%重试开销：每个代理任务成本约为0.05-0.10美元。若每日处理1000个任务，每月API支出约1500-3000美元。重试开销才是隐藏的真实成本——多数成本对比假设完美执行，但工具调用代理常存在解析失败、需验证重试等问题。我曾见重试率使实际成本比基准预测高出40-60%。对于高吞吐量且能容忍延迟的工作负载，本地模型以推理速度降低50倍换取近乎零边际成本的优势开始显得极具吸引力。

posts.abstract:
这是一个2026年2月的HackerNews招聘主题帖，核心话题是科技公司发布招聘信息，旨在为招聘方和求职者提供一个直接对接的平台。帖子本身是招聘方发布职位信息的格式规范，要求注明工作地点（远程、现场等）、公司简介，并强调只接受公司直接招聘而非中介。

从社区讨论中提取的用户观点主要围绕各类公司的招聘广告展开。这些公司涵盖在线教育、医疗软件、去中心化技术、材料科学、开发工具、医疗数据、云计算和AI制药等多个前沿领域。普遍共识是，该帖子是一个高质量、信息集中的招聘渠道，许多公司提供了清晰的职位描述和业务介绍。

讨论中呈现的多元观点主要体现在对不同行业和职位类型的关注上。例如，有人认为远程工作机会增多（如StraighterLine、Innolitics），也有用户指出现场或混合办公模式依然存在（如Apple要求每周3天到岗）。此外，不同公司的工作方向差异显著，从医疗AI合规到原子模拟，再到开源技术投资，反映出科技就业市场的广泛多样性。整体而言，社区通过这个帖子展示了2026年初科技招聘的趋势：远程工作普遍但非绝对，且深度技术领域（如AI、生物科技、基础设施）需求旺盛。

posts.title: Data centers in space makes no sense
posts.author: ajyoon
posts.title_cn: 太空数据中心毫无意义
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“太空数据中心是否可行”展开，多数用户认为这一想法缺乏实际意义。核心争议点集中在技术可行性与经济成本上：有人指出太空真空环境导致散热只能依赖辐射，冷却效率远低于地面；也有用户强调发射成本极高，且维修、带宽连接存在瓶颈。部分观点怀疑其动机，认为这可能是受科幻概念影响的投资噱头，或为了规避政府监管。讨论中提到，若真要迁移工业与数据中心，月球因拥有水源和材料或许比轨道更合理。尽管存在少数支持性论点（如太空太阳能优势），但社区普遍认为该方案现阶段不切实际，且未充分考虑可靠性、延迟等现实约束。

comments.author: beloch
comments.content: I would not assume cooling has been worked out.Space is a vacuum.  i.e. The lack-of-a-thing that makes a thermos great at keeping your drink hot.  A satellite is, if nothing else, a fantastic thermos.  A data center in space would necessarily rely completely on cooling by radiation, unlike a terrestrial data center that can make use of convection and conduction. You can't just pipe heat out into the atmosphere or build a heat exchanger. You can't exchange heat with vacuum.  You can only radiate heat into it.Heat is going to limit the compute that can be done in a satellite data centre and radiative cooling solutions are going to massively increase weight. It makes far more sense to build data centers in the arctic.Musk is up to something here.  This could be another hyperloop (i.e. A distracting promise meant to sabotage competition).  It could be a legal dodge.  It could be a power grab.  What it will not be is a useful source of computing power.  Anyone who takes this venture seriously is probably going to be burned.
comments.content_cn:
我不认为散热问题已经解决。太空是真空环境，这种"无物质"特性正是保温杯能保持饮品温度的关键。卫星本质上就是一个超级保温杯。与能利用对流和传导散热的地面数据中心不同，太空数据中心必须完全依赖辐射冷却。你无法简单地将热量排入大气或建造热交换器——真空环境无法进行热交换，只能通过辐射散热。

热量问题将严重限制卫星数据中心的计算能力，而辐射冷却方案会大幅增加设备重量。在北极建设数据中心远比这合理得多。

马斯克此举必有深意。这可能像超级高铁项目那样（即用干扰性承诺打击竞争对手），也可能是法律规避手段，或是权力争夺策略。但绝不可能是有效的算力来源。任何认真对待这个项目的人都可能遭受损失。

comments.author: phire
comments.content: As far as I can tell, Data centres in space only seem viable because their advocates insist on comparing them to standard terrestrial data centres.And nobody ever calls them out on it.Today's data centres are optimised for reliability, redundancy, density, repairability, connectivity and latency. Most of advertised savings come not from placing the data centre in space, but the fact that advocates have argued away the need for absolutely everything that modern data centres are designed to supply, except for the compute.If they can really build a space data centre satellite for as cheap as they claim, why launch it? Just drive it out into the middle of the desert and dump it there. It can access the internet via starlink, and already has solar panels for power and radiators for cooling. IMO, If it can cool itself in direct sunlight in space, it can cool itself in the desert.The main thing that space gains you over setting up the same satellite in the desert is ~23 hours of power, vs the ~12 hours of power on the ground. And you suddenly gain the ability to repair the satellite. The cost of the launch would have to be extremely cheap before the extra 11ish hours of runtime per day outweighed the cost of a launch; Just build twice as many "ground satellites".And that's with a space optimised design. We can gain even more cost savings by designing proper distributed datacenter elements. You don't need lightweight materials, just use steel. You can get rid of the large radiators and become more reliant on air cooling. You can built each element bigger, because you don't have to fit the rocket dimensions. You could even add a wind turbine, so your daily runtime isn't dependant on daylight hours. Might even be worth getting rid of solar and optimising for wind power instead.An actual ground optimised design should be able to deliver the same functionality as the space data centre, for much cheaper costs. And it's this ground optimised distributed design that space data centres should be compared to, not today's datacenter which are hyper-optimised for pre-AI use cases.-------------------Space data centres are nothing more than a cool Sci-Fi solution looking for a problem. There have been mumblings for years, but they were never viable (even bitcoin mining was a bit too latency sensitive). Space data centre advocates have been handed a massive win with this recent AI boom, it's the perfect problem for their favourite solution to solve.But because it's a solution looking for a problem, they are completely blind to other solutions that might be an even better fit.
comments.content_cn:
在我看来，太空数据中心之所以显得可行，完全是因为支持者坚持将其与标准的地面数据中心进行比较，却从未有人质疑这种对比的合理性。现代数据中心的设计核心在于可靠性、冗余性、密度、可维护性、连接性和低延迟。他们所宣传的成本节省并非源于将数据中心置于太空，而是因为支持者刻意忽略了现代数据中心除计算能力外所提供的一切必要功能。

如果他们真能如其所言低成本建造太空数据中心卫星，为何还要发射升空？直接将其运到沙漠深处放置即可。它完全可以通过星链接入互联网，本身已配备太阳能板供电和散热器冷却。在我看来，若能在太空直射阳光下实现自主冷却，在沙漠环境中同样可以做到。

相比在沙漠部署同类卫星，太空环境的主要优势在于每日约23小时的供电时长，而地面仅有约12小时。但与此同时，你却突然获得了维修卫星的能力。除非发射成本极其低廉，否则每日多出的11小时运行时间根本不足以抵消发射费用——不如直接建造两倍数量的“地面卫星”。

这还是基于太空优化设计的情况。若采用合理的分布式数据中心组件设计，我们还能进一步降低成本：无需轻质材料，普通钢材即可；可省去大型散热器……

comments.author: elamje
comments.content: I was talking to someone about this the other day. I was part of a team at NASA that developed a cooling system for the ISS and this whole premise makes no sense to me.1. Getting things to space is incredibly expensive2. Ingress/egress are almost always a major bottleneck - how is bandwidth cheaper in space?3. Chips must be “Rad-hard” - that is do more error correcting from ionizing radiation - there were entire teams at NASA dedicated to special hardware for this.4. Gravity and atmospheric pressure actually do wonders for easy cooling. Heat is not dissipated in space like we are all used to and you must burn additional energy trying to move the heat generated away from source.5. Energy production will be cheaper from earth due to mass manufacturing of necessary components in energy systems - space energy systems need novel technology where economies of scale are lost.Would love for someone to make the case for why it actually makes total sense, because it’s really hard to see for me!
comments.content_cn: 前几天我还和人讨论过这个话题。作为NASA团队的一员，我曾参与国际空间站冷却系统的研发，因此在我看来这个设想完全站不住脚：1. 将物资送入太空的成本极其高昂；2. 进出通道几乎总是主要瓶颈——太空中的带宽怎么可能更便宜？3. 芯片必须达到"抗辐射"标准，即需要针对电离辐射进行更多纠错处理，NASA曾为此设立专门团队研发特殊硬件；4. 重力和大气压力其实对散热大有裨益，太空中热量无法像我们习惯的那样自然消散，必须额外消耗能量将产生的热量从源头转移；5. 由于能源系统组件可在地球大规模生产，地球的能源生产成本会更低，而太空能源系统需要新技术，无法形成规模经济。很希望有人能论证这个设想的合理性，因为在我看来实在难以理解！

comments.content: (DTC) Datacentres take electricity and turn it into low grade heat e.g 60c water. Put them anywhere where you've either got excess (cheap) energy or where you can use the heat. comments.author: dathinab
comments.content: The really crazy thing is you don't need to know more then basic (non Hollywood) physics to know how dump this is1. every gram you need to send to space is costly, a issue you don't have at ground level2. cooling is a catastrophe, sure space is cold, but also a vacuum, so the cooling rate is roughly the infrared radiation rate. This means if you are not careful with the surface of a satellite it can end up being very slowly cooked by sunlight alone not including running any higher heat producing component (as it absorbs more heat from sunlight then it emits, there is a reason satellites are mostly white, silver or reflective gold in color). Sure better surface materials fix that, but not to a point where you would want to run any heavy compute on it.3. zero repair-ability, most long running satellites have a lot of redundancy. Also at least if you are bulk buying Nvidea GPGPUs on single digit Million Euro basis it's not rare that 30% have some level of defect. Not necessary "fully broken" but "performs less good then it should/compared to other units" kind of broken.4. radiation/solar wind protections are a huge problem. Heck even if you run things on earth it's a problem as long as your operations scale is large enough. In space things are magnitudes worse.5. every rocket lunch causes atmospheric damage, so does every satellite evaporating on re-entry. That wasn't that relevant in the past, but might become a problem just for keeping stuff like Starlink running. We don't need to make it worse by putting datacenters into space.6. Kessler Syndrom is real and could seriously hurt humanity as a whole, no reason to make it much more likely by putting things into space which don't need to go there.Last but not least, wtf would you even want to do it?There is zero benefit, non nada.
comments.content_cn: 真正疯狂的是，你只需要懂基础（非好莱坞式）物理就能明白这有多蠢。1. 每克送上太空的物质都代价高昂，这是地面不存在的问题。2. 散热简直是灾难——太空确实寒冷，但也是真空环境，冷却速率基本取决于红外辐射率。这意味着如果卫星表面处理不当，仅凭阳光照射就可能让它被慢慢“烤熟”，更别提运行任何高发热元件了（因为吸收的太阳热量会超过散失量，这就是卫星多为白色、银色或反光金色的原因）。更好的表面材料确实能缓解问题，但远不足以支撑在太空进行高强度计算。3. 完全无法维修——多数长期运行的卫星都依赖大量冗余设计。况且，就算你花几百万欧元批量采购英伟达计算卡，30%存在不同程度缺陷也很常见，不一定是“完全损坏”，但会出现“性能低于应有水平/相比其他单元表现不佳”的情况。4. 辐射/太阳风防护是巨大难题。说实话，就算在地面运行，只要规模够大这都是问题，而在太空情况会恶劣数个量级。5. 每次火箭发射都会破坏大气层，每颗卫星再入烧毁同样如此。过去这或许不重要，但光是维持星链这类系统运行就可能引发新问题。我们不需要……

comments.author: tgbugs
comments.content: One way to work around the heat dissipation issues in space (and also on earth) is to move to computing systems that operate entirely at cryogenic temperatures to take advantage of superconducting circuitry.I've heard stories that over a decade ago teams inside hyperscalars had calculated that running completely cryogenically cooled data centers would be vastly cheaper than what we do now due to savings on resistive losses and the cost of eliminating waste heat. You don't have to get rid of heat that you don't generate in the first place.The issue is that at the moment there are very few IC components and processes that have been engineered to run at cryogenic temperatures. Replicating the entirety of the existing data center stack for cryogenic temps is nowhere near reality.That said, once you have cryogenic superconducting integrated circuits you could colocate your data centers and your propellant/oxidizer depots. Not exactly "data centers off in deep space" since propoxd tend to be the highest traffic areas.
comments.content_cn: 解决太空（以及地球）散热问题的一种途径是转向完全在低温环境下运行的计算机系统，以利用超导电路的优势。我听说十多年前，超大规模计算团队曾估算过，完全采用低温冷却的数据中心运行成本将远低于现有模式，这得益于电阻损耗的减少以及无需处理废热带来的成本节约——根本无需处理那些未曾产生的热量。问题在于，目前极少有集成电路组件和工艺是为低温运行而设计的。要在低温环境下复制现有数据中心的完整技术体系，离现实还非常遥远。不过，一旦拥有了低温超导集成电路，就可以将数据中心与推进剂/氧化剂存储设施并置。这严格来说并非“深空数据中心”，因为推进剂存储区往往是运输最繁忙的区域。

如果你正在寻找工作，请分享你的信息。请使用以下格式：
  地点：
  是否接受远程工作：
  是否愿意搬迁：
  技术栈：
  简历/履历：
  电子邮件：

请仅在你个人寻找工作时发布。中介、招聘人员、招聘网站等与此无关。
读者：请仅通过电子邮件联系这些地址讨论工作机会。
有一个网站可用于搜索这些帖子：https://www.wantstobehired.com。
posts.abstract:
这是一个HackerNews论坛上每月发布的“谁想被雇佣”求职主题帖。核心话题是为正在寻找工作的技术人员提供一个直接发布个人信息的平台，格式统一，便于潜在雇主联系。

社区讨论中，不同用户主要展示了各自的技术栈、工作地点偏好和求职状态。普遍共识是，大多数求职者都接受远程工作，并且技术栈集中在现代主流开发工具和框架上，如Python、JavaScript/TypeScript、React、Node.js以及各类云服务和AI相关技术。

主要观点和分歧点体现在工作地点灵活性上。有人认为远程工作是首选甚至强制要求，例如用户1、2、6明确表示不愿或目前不愿搬迁。也有用户指出愿意搬迁，但范围有限，如用户4只考虑省内搬迁。讨论中提到，部分用户对搬迁持开放态度，用户3、7、8、9、10表示愿意为机会而搬迁，其中用户7和8更是对全球机会持开放态度。此外，用户5和10虽然接受远程，但分别倾向于留在湾区或偏好混合办公模式。整体上，社区成员通过简洁格式高效地传递了关键求职信息。

posts.title: New York’s budget bill would require “blocking technology” on all 3D printers
posts.author: ptorrone
posts.title_cn: 纽约预算案拟要求所有3D打印机配备“阻断技术”
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕纽约预算案要求所有3D打印机安装“阻断技术”的提案展开。核心争议在于该政策对遏制非法活动（如打印枪支）的实际效果及其对普通用户的负面影响。

多数用户认为该法案脱离实际：有人指出技术限制极易被绕过，如同DRM常被破解；也有用户强调自制3D打印机或使用数控机床更易获得，法案反而会阻碍正常使用，导致“缺一种颜色就无法黑白打印”的荒诞情况。讨论中提到，英国虽管制刀具却未推行类似技术限制，因“无人用3D打印机造枪”且此举是“解决伪问题的不可行方案”。

分歧点集中在立法动机与权利层面：部分用户批评法案仅增加合规负担却无法阻止恶意行为；另有观点从宪法角度质疑，认为这可能违反第四修正案（不合理搜查）甚至第一修正案（若打印属言论自由）。共识在于该提案缺乏实操性，可能迫使厂商退出纽约市场，最终“什么问题都解决不了”。

comments.author: eggy
comments.content: I built an 8'x4' CNC router table in 2004. I bought rack and pinion, steppers, drives, aluminum extrusion, and I had it built in one week. What would stop someone from building their own printer and building and selling printers to others who don't have the skill set? They would make it illegal to make 3D printers or CNC machinery without a license, and if you are caught it is tantamount to making guns.
comments.content_cn: 我在2004年造了一个8英尺乘4英尺的数控雕刻机工作台。我买了齿条齿轮、步进电机、驱动器、铝型材，一周内就把它组装好了。有什么能阻止人们自己制造打印机，并把打印机卖给那些没有相关技能的人呢？他们会规定无许可证制造3D打印机或数控机床属于非法行为，一旦被抓到，就等同于制造枪支。

comments.author: pigpop
comments.content: Once again another proposed law that would just make normal people's lives more difficult while doing nothing to prevent individuals who are motivated to do the illegal thing from doing it. Offline 3D printers are really not difficult to build, there are many open source plans and all of the hardware is available to order from AliExpress making it simple to do. Somewhat more technically capable people can cobble them together from alternative sources if they don't want to purchase things online.But the bar is even lower than that since you can simply buy a gun much more easily than you could 3D print parts for one.
comments.content_cn: 这又是一项只会让普通人生活更困难、却无法阻止有意违法者实施非法行为的提案。离线3D打印机制作其实并不困难，网上有许多开源方案，所有硬件都能在速卖通轻松订购。技术能力稍强的人若不愿在线购物，完全可以通过其他渠道拼装设备。但实际门槛甚至更低——毕竟直接购买枪支比用3D打印零件组装要容易得多。

comments.content: This will cause 3D printer usability to go down massively. A bit like the multicolored tracking dots - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Printer_tracking_dots that causes the driver to tell you "you can't print black and white as you're out of yellow".

posts.title_cn: Todd C. Miller – Sudo 维护者逾 30 载
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了资深开发者Todd C. Miller维护sudo工具超过30年的贡献。核心话题围绕开源基础设施的长期维护及其对现代互联网的关键作用。

社区普遍对Miller的持续工作表示敬意，有用户感叹sudo至今仍保持活跃开发和月度更新，打破了“软件终会完成”的误解。许多人认同像sudo、curl和openssl这样的核心工具依赖于少数维护者的长期奉献，这种状况既令人敬佩也引发担忧。讨论中提到，这类基础软件虽常被忽视，却支撑着整个互联网的运转。

存在不同观点：有人认为开源文化已从早期的“自由软件”理念转向更注重实际效用的模式；也有用户指出，公众对维护者的经济支持不足，半开玩笑地建议“sudo pay him”。此外，部分讨论延伸至其他类似维护者（如NTP协议的维护者）的故事，强调基础设施维护者的隐形贡献。整体上，社区一致认可Miller作为传奇人物的地位，并对其工作表示深切感谢。

comments.author: arjie
comments.content: I think the rise of the open-source redistributor groupie has been an interesting cultural revolution. I wonder if it will persist. Even 10 years ago, the idea of Free As In Speech dominated the idea of Free Software. Today, the greatest enthusiasm on Hacker News and Reddit is for something like Meta's Llama license (which cannot be used by people or corps with sufficient numbers of users). It certainly seems like someone out there could go out and propose the Microfree License which only applies to sufficiently non-rich people.For my part, I want none of it. I find this reduction of a significant philosophy to some kind of base tax-and-distribute mechanism distasteful. I don't like communities were this stuff is big and they always want to run some taxation scheme where they redirect money to their own personal pet projects. It is fortunate that modern tools are good enough to build personal insulation from this stuff.Imagine the farce of Apply HN repeated continuously. Simply awful.
comments.content_cn:
我认为开源再分发追随者的兴起是一场有趣的文化革命。我好奇这种现象能否持续下去。即便在十年前，“自由如言论”的理念仍主导着自由软件运动。如今，Hacker News和Reddit上最热衷讨论的却是像Meta的Llama许可证这类协议（该许可证禁止用户数超过一定规模的个人或公司使用）。看起来完全可能有人提出“微自由许可证”，只适用于资产未达特定门槛的人群。

就我个人而言，我对这些毫无兴趣。将重要的哲学理念简化为某种基础的税收再分配机制令人反感。我不喜欢那些热衷此道的社区，他们总想推行各种税收方案，将资金引流到自己钟爱的私人项目上。幸好现代工具足够强大，能让个人与这类事物保持距离。

想象一下“Apply HN”这种闹剧不断重演的场景，简直糟糕透顶。

comments.author: shevy-java
comments.content: I disagree on "the most critical" part. You can be superuser at all times. I understand the arguments why not; I am pointing out that this is possible. Despite people claiming aliens will arrive and nothing will work, everything works fine when the superuser account is used too.Also, I disagree that every company needs to pay the man. Funding is important, yes, but a *nix system is not crippled without sudo. You can change the permission systems. The superuser can do so too. It is not black magic. The permission system is trivial. sudo is simply a feature of convenience, not a "if sudo does not exist, nothing works" - that just makes no sense.
comments.content_cn: 我不同意“最关键”这个说法。你可以始终使用超级用户权限。我理解反对的理由，但我要指出这是可行的。尽管有人声称外星人来了系统就会崩溃，但使用超级账户时一切运行正常。此外，我也不同意每个公司都必须为此付费。资金确实重要，但*nix系统没有sudo也不会瘫痪。你可以修改权限系统，超级用户同样能做到。这不是什么神秘操作，权限系统其实很简单。sudo只是便利性功能，并非“没有sudo就寸步难行”——这种说法毫无道理。

Specification wise, sudo is "done". It does what it needs to, it's interface is defined and there aren't going to be any strange surprises when I run sudo between any system made in the past 10 years or so.The problem is that when you're selling software, demanding compensation for the former is a hard sell since it's things customers won't see or necessarily care about. posts.title: Defeating a 40-year-old copy protection dongle
posts.author: zdw
posts.title_cn: 击败一款有40年历史的加密狗保护技术
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕一篇关于破解40年前软件加密狗的技术文章展开。核心话题是回顾早期软件版权保护技术的演进及其破解方法。有人认为早期保护机制较为简单，如通过调试对比执行路径、修改跳转指令即可绕过；也有用户指出90年代中期的HASP等硬件保护已更复杂，甚至将部分数据存储在加密狗内存中。讨论中提到，尽管技术不断升级，但最坚固的保护通常也能在一周内被破解。

争议点主要集中在法律与伦理层面：有用户质疑公开破解方法是否合法，特别是依据DMCA第1201条；也有用户指出企业软件商常利用版权保护向客户过度收费，暗示破解可能具有合理性。共识在于早期保护机制设计相对朴素，现代软件已更多依赖许可证密钥而非硬件加密，因为企业客户通常愿意付费。技术爱好者普遍认同破解过程的关键在于定位并理解保护逻辑的实现位置。

comments.author: sedatk

I specifically remember software that kept a portion of its data in the dongle memory with good anti-debugging techniques too. But even the hardest protection would take a week to break at most.
comments.content_cn: 当然，早期的时候确实很简单。到了90年代中期，随着HASP等技术的出现，情况大为改观，速度也快了很多。我特别记得有些软件会将部分数据存储在加密狗内存中，并采用了出色的反调试技术。但即便是最严密的保护，最多也只需一周就能破解。

We can see in this article that this company was still using Windows 98 - they're clearly locked-in!All of which is to say that this intellectual property might actually still be owned by a company who'll be able to sue.If you haven't already checked whether the patent and other intellectual property is still owned by any company, OP, I would strongly suggest doing so first.

comments.content: Another poster found grabs of the company's website on archive.org. The last date it existed to be grabbed was in 2001. I think the OP is fine on this one.Other than that, there's virtually no mention of the company or software anywhere online. Just to put that in context, I'm in the vintage computer / software community where thousands of amateur historians and archivists scour obscure corners looking for old, unknown software apps to preserve. Software sold for Windows 98 up to 2001 (so recent as to barely be considered 'vintage') with so little online footprint means it must have been incredibly obscure. No ads or reviews from magazines or even newsletters means there's a good chance it was a one or two person part-time, home-based business and the product had hundreds or maybe even just dozens of users.1998-2001 was the hottest time ever for PC software. I worked in marketing Windows software during this period. To have any commercial Windows software product actively available for sale in the late 90s with no surviving footprint would almost require intentional effort to stay unknown. No press releases mailed. No review copies sent. No shows or conferences attended (exhibitor listings are searchable online now). There were much older niche vertical software programs for much more obscure platforms which we know sold less than a hundred copies ever, yet still have a larger online footprint than this program. The OP de-protecting and archiving this previously unknown commercial program represents quite a notable find in the preservation community.

1998-2001年是PC软件最火热的时期。我当时从事Windows软件营销工作。在90年代末，任何正常销售的商业Windows软件要想完全不留网络痕迹，几乎需要刻意保持隐匿状态：不发布新闻稿、不寄送评测副本、不参加展会活动（现在参展商名录都能在线查到）。即便是针对更冷门平台的古老垂直领域软件，那些已知销量不足百份的产品，其网络痕迹也比这款软件丰富得多。原帖主对这款此前无人知晓的商业软件进行脱壳和存档的行为……

comments.author: 51Cards
comments.content: I was hired in the early 90's by a collection of franchises for a home care company.  The privately owned head office self-developed and distributed required monthly updates to the only software franchises were permitted to run their business.  The monthly updates (floppies) reset the license for another month at each location.  After years of problems, poor support, and in a couple cases offices getting shut down because head office just "didn't like them anymore", they banded together to sue the owners (one of which developed the software).  I did IT work for a couple of the offices and was already familiar with maintaining the software / systems.  They hired me to bypass the licensing code which was a lot of fun to figure out.  In the end I wrote a DOS based license generator each office had that could update their software by just getting a code over the phone for the upcoming month (or any date for 365 days).  A few years later once the lawsuit settled and the company broke apart we issued a patch for the software to remove the license check completely.  I should fire up DOSBox sometime so I can play with that old software again.
comments.content_cn: 九十年代初，我被一家家庭护理公司的多家特许经营商联合聘用。这家公司的私有总部自行开发并分发唯一允许特许经营商运营业务的软件，且每月强制更新。每月更新的软盘会为每个营业点重置为期一个月的使用许可。历经多年问题频发、技术支持薄弱，甚至有几家营业点仅因总部“不再喜欢他们”而被强行关闭后，这些特许经营商联合起诉了公司所有者（其中一人正是该软件的开发者）。我曾为其中几家营业点提供信息技术支持，早已熟悉该软件及系统的维护工作。他们聘请我破解许可验证代码，这个过程充满探索乐趣。最终我为每个营业点编写了基于DOS系统的许可生成器，只需通过电话获取下个月（或未来365天内任意日期）的激活码即可更新软件。数年后诉讼和解、公司解体，我们发布了永久移除许可验证的软件补丁。真该找个时间打开DOSBox模拟器，再玩玩那个老软件。

comments.content_cn: 我仍在开发需要硬件加密狗的软件。大约15年前，我们从并口转向USB-A接口，至今仍在使用USB-A，这让近年购买新笔记本电脑的用户颇为不便。如今破解难度有所增加，因为我们采用特殊编译器，利用加密狗内的密钥对二进制文件进行加密，仅在加载后才进行解密。使用加密狗的一个重要原因是为了实现功能区域控制（例如A国用户不得拥有X功能，而B国用户则可以使用），并能对离线桌面软件设置"过期"机制。

comments.author: hinkley
comments.content: There's a lot of things going on that lead to this.One, the developers spend more time running this code than we do, and they have to get the program working before we can even use it. So any parts of the program that are hostile to the developers risks killing the entire project. Obfuscating the copy protection can hit a point where it makes bug fixing difficult.Two, lack of training. If you, me, and Steve each have a bag of tricks we all use to crack games, whichever one of us figures it out gets bragging rights but the game remains cracked. Meanwhile Developer Dan has to be aware of all the tricks in all of our bags together if he wants to keep the three of us out. Only there's not three of us, there's 300. Or today, probably more like 30,000.Three, lack of motivation, which is itself several different situations. There's a certain amount of passive aggression you can put into a feature you don't even really want to work on. You can lean into any of the other explanations to defend why your code didn't protect from cracking all that much, but it's a checkbox that's trying to prove a negative, and nobody is going to give you any credit for getting it to work right in the same way they give you credit for fixing that corner glitch that the QA people keep bitching about. Or getting that particle animation to work that makes the AOE spells look badass.
comments.content_cn: 导致这种情况的原因有很多。其一，开发者运行这些代码的时间比我们长得多，他们必须让程序先正常运行我们才能使用。所以任何对开发者不友好的部分都可能危及整个项目。过度混淆的版权保护可能达到让修复漏洞变得困难的程度。其二，缺乏系统训练。如果你、我和史蒂夫各自有一套破解游戏的技巧，谁先破解成功谁就能炫耀，但游戏终究会被破解。而开发者丹如果想阻止我们三人，就必须同时掌握我们所有人的技巧。可问题是我们不止三人，而是三百人。放到今天，可能接近三万人。其三，动力不足，这本身又涉及多种情况。对于自己并不真想投入的功能，开发者可能会带有某种消极抵触情绪。你可以用其他理由来解释为什么你的代码没能有效防止破解，但这就像试图证明否定命题的复选框——即使做对了也没人会像称赞你修复QA人员反复抱怨的角落故障那样给予肯定，或是像赞赏你实现让范围法术看起来炫酷的粒子动画那样给予认可。

comments.author: markh1967
comments.content: Many years ago I was a technician supporting a few custom programs on thousands of PCs. The developer of one of these programs had added a date check to his code so the program would refuse to run after a set date and each new release would increase this date by a few months so it would stop working after a few weeks if he ever stopped creating new releases. His contract ended and a few weeks later his software, now relied upon by hundreds of sites, stopped working. The contract for the software development was thoroughly checked and legal action against the developer was started but I asked to see if I could resolve the problem in the meantime.It only took ten minutes with a dissassembler to find the JGT (Jump if greater than) and convert it to a JLT so the software would stop running if the date was before a certain date rather than after. I created a patching tool that simply flipped one bit that was sent out to all the sites and everything was good again. I don't think I'll ever beat the elegance of a single bit flip hack.
comments.content_cn: 多年前，我曾是一名技术员，负责维护数千台电脑上的几个定制程序。其中一款程序的开发者在代码中添加了日期检查功能，使得程序在设定日期后无法运行，而每个新版本都会将这个日期推迟几个月。这样一来，如果他停止发布新版本，几周后程序就会失效。他的合同结束后不久，这款已被数百个站点依赖的软件果然停止了工作。软件开发合同经过仔细审查，并对该开发者提起了法律诉讼，但我请求尝试在此期间解决问题。使用反汇编工具仅花了十分钟，我就找到了JGT（大于则跳转）指令，并将其改为JLT（小于则跳转），这样软件只会在日期早于某个特定日期时停止运行，而不是晚于。我创建了一个修补工具，只需翻转一个比特位，然后将其分发给所有站点，一切便恢复正常。我至今仍觉得，这种仅靠翻转一个比特位的破解方式堪称优雅至极。

comments.author: userbinator
comments.content: For some reason, Reko was not able to decompile this code into a C representationThat's likely because it's one of those (of which many existed) which attempt to dumbly pattern-match against what a typical C compiler of the time (with equally dumb and extremely inefficient code generation) would do, but that routine clearly looks like handwritten Asm. I've never seen a C compiler from that era generate a LOOP instruction, for example, and of course "cli" nor the I/O instructions are not expressable except perhaps as intrinsics. Ghidra might be a bit better at this, as it's a generalised decompiler.In fact, when the compiler (RPGC.EXE) compiles some RPG source code, it seems to copy the parallel port routine from itself into the compiled program.This reminds me of the classic Ken Thompson attack.
comments.content_cn: 出于某种原因，Reko未能将此代码反编译为C语言表示形式。这可能是因为它属于那种（当时存在许多类似情况）试图简单模式匹配当时典型C编译器（其代码生成同样笨拙且效率极低）行为的工具，但该例程显然看起来像是手写的汇编代码。例如，我从未见过那个时代的C编译器生成LOOP指令，当然“cli”和I/O指令也无法直接表达，或许只能通过内置函数实现。Ghidra在这方面可能稍好一些，因为它是一个通用反编译器。实际上，当编译器（RPGC.EXE）编译某些RPG源代码时，它似乎会将并行端口例程从自身复制到编译后的程序中。这让我想起了经典的Ken Thompson攻击。

comments.author: nsoonhui
comments.content: I write civil engineering software [0] and am familiar with this kind of dongle. Yes, even today there are users who want this kind of dongle instead of, say, cloud-based validation. They feel secure only if they have something tangible in hand.Since we sold (and still sell) perpetual licenses, it becomes a problem when a dongle breaks and replacement parts are no longer available. Not all users want to upgrade. Also, you may hate cloud licensing, but it is precisely cloud licensing that makes subscriptions possible and, therefore, recurring revenue—which, from a business point of view, is especially important in a field where regulations do not change very fast, because users have little incentive to upgrade.Also, despite investing a lot of effort into programming the dongle, we can still usually find cracked versions floating online, even on legitimate platforms like Shopee or Lazada. You might think cracking dongles is fun and copy protection is evil, but without protection, our livelihood is affected. It’s not as if we have the legal resources to pursue pirates.[0]: https://mes100.com
comments.content_cn:
我从事土木工程软件开发[0]，对这类加密狗很熟悉。是的，即便在今天，仍有用户想要这种硬件加密狗，而非云端验证。他们觉得只有手里握着实物才有安全感。由于我们销售（且仍在销售）永久许可证，当加密狗损坏且替换零件停产时就会很麻烦——并非所有用户都愿意升级。另外，你可能讨厌云端授权，但正是云端授权使订阅制成为可能，从而带来持续收入。从商业角度看，这在行业规范更新缓慢的领域尤为重要，因为用户缺乏升级动力。此外，尽管我们在加密狗编程上投入大量精力，仍常能在网上找到破解版本，甚至在Shopee或Lazada等正规平台也有流通。你可能觉得破解加密狗很有趣而版权保护很可恶，但若没有保护，我们的生计就会受影响。我们并没有足够的法律资源去追查盗版者。

comments.content: In the 80s I worked on BPCS, an early ERP system, and yes it was coded in RPG2, and RPG3. comments.content_cn: 八十年代我曾参与BPCS系统的开发，这是一套早期的ERP系统，确实采用RPG2和RPG3语言编写。源代码的理解难度令人咋舌，但我认为正是那段经历让我后来觉得AWK语言如此简单且符合逻辑。当时IBM刚推出小型System36主机，外观像是米白色的个人电脑机箱，如果没记错的话，这其实是精简版的s/36系统。市场反响并不理想。后来还出现过DOS版的RPG，我有所耳闻但未曾使用。若文中作者的客户四十年来一直使用RPG会计系统，那很可能是BPCS系统，市面上已有工具能将RPG转换为其他更易驾驭的语言。这篇文章依然引人入胜，勾起了我担任应用程序员的回忆。我也记得那些加密狗——当多个应用程序各自配备加密狗却只有一个接口时，场面真是令人哭笑不得。

comments.author: zzzeek
comments.content: my story of this is Atari Macro Assembler.   The floppy had a specific sector that was damaged, and the loader would test this sector to ensure it was in fact damaged.  this was obvious becuase whenever loading the floppy, you had to wait for one of those big "BZZT....BZZT" things where the 810 drive was trying to access a bad sector and giving up.   I was able to disassemble maybe the first 30 bytes of the boot to see it checking this and doing the jmp.   I just overwrote it with a single jmp and got not just a copy but much faster loading without the BZZTBZZT part.
comments.content_cn: 我的故事是关于Atari宏汇编器的。那张软盘有一个特定扇区是损坏的，而加载程序会测试这个扇区以确保它确实已损坏。这一点很明显，因为每次加载软盘时，你都得等待那种“哔滋……哔滋”的巨大声响，那是810驱动器试图访问坏扇区并最终放弃的过程。我反汇编了大约前30个字节的引导程序，看到它在检查这个扇区并进行跳转。我直接用一个简单的跳转指令覆盖了它，结果不仅得到了一个副本，而且加载速度大大加快，再也没有了“哔滋哔滋”的部分。

comments.author: spicyjpeg
comments.content: Plenty of low-volume industrial software has never really moved on from security dongles. Most modern arcade games for instance still rely on a USB dongle to decrypt game files [1], though nowadays they typically also come with an additional layer of TPM-backed encryption as well as always online DRM (many of them are region locked and operate on a revenue share contract, where the owner has to pay a per-play fee to the game manufacturer).These measures typically work well against piracy in the markets the game is officially distributed in (mainly Japan), but end up being cracked anyway once the game is popular enough that foreign arcades and private owners start importing older decommissioned cabinets and create demand for a way to get them running again without depending on the manufacturer's servers.[1]: https://mon.im/2017/12/konami-arcade-drm
comments.content_cn: 许多低销量的工业软件至今仍未真正摆脱安全加密锁的依赖。以现代街机游戏为例，大多数仍依靠USB加密锁来解密游戏文件[1]，尽管如今它们通常还会额外增加基于TPM的加密层以及始终在线的数字版权管理（许多游戏设有区域限制并采用收益分成合约，经营者需按次向游戏厂商支付费用）。这些措施在游戏官方发行市场（主要是日本）通常能有效防止盗版，但一旦游戏足够受欢迎，外国街机厅和私人收藏者开始引进淘汰的老旧机台，并催生出摆脱厂商服务器独立运行的需求时，最终仍会被破解。[1]: https://mon.im/2017/12/konami-arcade-drm

comments.author: miki123211
comments.content: Another method (much more common for software that asks for two pieces of information, like a name and a key) is to take a memdump of the process at the "your key is invalid" dialog, find the invalid key you just typed, and hope that a valid key is somewhere nearby in memory. Unlike the assembly trick, this requires 0 programming expertise beyond the ability to type `strings` on the command line.This works because some programs use a hashing algorithm to calculate the key based on the name, do a strcmp, and pop a messagebox if the keys don't match, without zeroizing the valid key buffer first. If the key buffers are on the stack (or if the two mallocs just happen to use the same region in memory), it is often easy to find a valid key if you know where the invalid one is.I guess software that derives keys this way is far less common than it once was, but I know of somebody who cracked something using this method just a few years ago, so it still pops up from time to time.
comments.content_cn: 另一种方法（在需要输入两项信息的软件中更为常见，比如姓名和密钥）是在弹出“密钥无效”对话框时对进程进行内存转储，找到刚刚输入的无效密钥，并期望在内存附近找到有效密钥。与汇编技巧不同，这种方法除了需要在命令行中输入`strings`外，完全不需要编程专业知识。这种方法之所以有效，是因为某些程序会使用哈希算法根据姓名计算密钥，然后进行字符串比较，如果密钥不匹配就弹出提示框，但并未事先清空有效密钥缓冲区。如果密钥缓冲区位于堆栈中（或者两次内存分配恰好使用了同一内存区域），只要知道无效密钥的位置，通常很容易找到有效密钥。我猜想采用这种方式生成密钥的软件已经比过去少得多，但我知道几年前还有人用这种方法破解过某些软件，所以这种情况仍时有发生。

It can be a shitload of work, but theoretically, there is no limits.With anything involving electronics - ranging from very simple circuitry to highly complex computer controls - the situation is much, much different. With stuff based on "common" technology, aka a good old x86 computer with RS232/DB25 interfaces, virtualization plus an I/O board can go a long way ensuring at least the hardware doesn't die, but if it's anything based on, say, Windows CE and an old Hitachi CPU? posts.title: Banning lead in gas worked. The proof is in our hair
posts.author: geox
posts.title_cn: 禁止含铅汽油成效显著，证据就在我们的头发中。
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕含铅汽油禁令的有效性展开，核心话题是环境监管的实际成效与当前挑战。多数用户认同禁止含铅汽油是成功的环境政策，有研究通过头发样本证明人体铅含量显著下降，这被视为明确证据。讨论中提到，铅污染对健康尤其是儿童智力发展有长期危害，因此普遍支持继续加强相关监管。

但讨论中也存在观点分歧。有人认为当前环境监管仍不足，例如航空燃油中的铅污染持续数十年未被有效控制，且燃煤导致的汞污染等问题亟待解决。也有用户指出，部分环境措施可能存在副作用，如替代材料（如陶瓷涂层）性能不佳，或食品中的铅掺假问题凸显监管漏洞。此外，有用户提及美国老年政治人物可能受铅毒影响，暗示禁令效果不够迅速。

整体上，社区共识是环境监管必要且有效，但需更全面、快速地应对各类污染源，同时关注政策执行中的新问题。

comments.author: cfiggers
comments.content: In my opinion it is obvious and should be uncontroversial that some environmental regulations work and are great and should if anything be reinforced, while other environmental regulations do more harm than good and need to be reigned in or eliminated.Turning "environmental regulation" into a unified bloc that must be either supported or opposed in totality is a manipulative political maneuver and it should be forcefully rejected.Regulations are not people, and they don't have rights. It is fair and reasonable to demand that environmental regulation justify its existence with hard, scientifically verifiable data or else get chopped. Clearly, banning leaded gasoline has that kind of justification, and therefore I'm strongly in favor of maintaining that ban and extending it wherever it isn't in place yet. The same reasonable standard should be applied to other regulations across the board.
comments.content_cn: 在我看来，某些环境法规行之有效且意义重大，甚至应当进一步加强，而另一些环境法规则弊大于利，需要加以约束或废除——这是显而易见且不应存在争议的。将“环境法规”塑造成一个必须全盘支持或全盘反对的统一阵营，是一种操纵性的政治手段，应当被坚决抵制。法规不是人，不享有权利。要求环境法规必须凭借可靠、可科学验证的数据证明其存在的合理性，否则就应被废除，这是公平且合理的。显然，禁止含铅汽油具备这样的合理性，因此我坚决支持维持这项禁令，并将其推广到尚未实施的地方。同样的合理标准应当全面适用于其他法规。

comments.author: throwway120385
comments.content: It's really easy to sit and demand evidence before regulating something. But consider that if we waited for hard evidence to accumulate before banning lead in gasoline, we likely never would have banned it because the hard evidence wouldn't exist.I also don't agree on the principle that regulations are "harmful" or "helpful."  Rather, you have to define who the regulation harms, and who it helps. For example antitrust enforcement harms shareholders and some employees of very large firms, but it helps many employees and arguably improves the landscape for competition between many smaller firms. So whether a regulation is preferable comes down to values.In the case of leaded gas, it harms basically everybody, but it helps fuel companies, so it was an easy thing to change.
comments.content_cn: 坐在那里要求先有证据再实施监管确实很容易。但试想一下，如果当初我们非要等到确凿证据才禁止含铅汽油，很可能永远都不会实施禁令，因为确凿证据根本不会出现。我也不同意监管"有害"或"有益"这种笼统说法。关键在于要明确监管损害了谁的利益，又保护了谁的利益。比如反垄断执法会损害大企业股东和部分员工的利益，但有利于众多员工，并且可以说为许多中小企业创造了更好的竞争环境。所以监管是否可取最终取决于价值取向。就含铅汽油而言，它基本上危害所有人，只对燃料公司有利，因此改变这种状况是理所当然的。

posts.title_cn: "1千字节正好是1000字节吗？"
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“1KB是否严格等于1000字节”展开，核心争议在于计算机存储单位应采用十进制（1000）还是二进制（1024）定义。有人认为，千（kilo）、兆（mega）等前缀在SI国际单位制中明确表示10的幂次，严格用于十进制，因此在存储领域使用1024属于误用。也有用户指出，计算机架构基于二进制寻址，使用2的幂次（如1024）具有实际工程意义，且历史惯例已广泛接受。讨论中提到，国际电工委员会（IEC）提出的“kibibyte”（KiB）等二进制单位旨在解决混淆，但部分用户认为其名称拗口、推广困难。分歧主要在于：一方坚持遵循SI标准以保持单位一致性，另一方则强调二进制单位在计算机系统中的实用性与传统。共识是当前混合使用状态容易造成误解，尤其对非专业人士而言。

comments.author: waffletower
comments.content: The author decidedly has expert syndrome -- they deny both the history and rational behind memory units nomenclature.  Memory measurements evolved utilizing binary organizational patterns used in computing architectures.  While a proud French pedant might agree with the decimal normalization of memory units discussed, it aligns more closely to the metric system, and it may have benefits for laypeople, it fails to account for how memory is partitioned in historic and modern computing.
comments.content_cn: 作者显然患有专家综合征——他们既否认内存单位命名的历史背景，也否认其理论基础。内存计量方式的演变源于计算机架构中采用的二进制组织模式。虽然一位骄傲的法国学究或许会赞同文中讨论的内存单位十进制标准化方案（因其更接近公制体系，且可能对普通用户更友好），但这种观点完全忽略了历史上及现代计算机中内存分配的实际运作方式。

comments.author: kstrauser
comments.content: I'm sticking with power-of-2 sizes. Invent a new word for decimal, metric units where appropriate. I proposed[0] "kitribytes", "metribytes", "gitribytes", etc. Just because "kilo" has a meaning in one context doesn't mean we're stuck with it in others. It's not as though the ancient Greeks originally meant "kilo" to mean "exactly 1,000". "Giga" just meant "giant". "Tera" is just "monster". SI doesn't have sole ownership for words meaning "much bigger than we can possibly count at a glance".Donald Knuth himself said[1]:> The members of those committees deserve credit for raising an important issue, but when I heard their proposal it seemed dead on arrival --- who would voluntarily want to use MiB for a maybe-byte?! So I came up with the suggestion above, and mentioned it on page 94 of my Introduction to MMIX. Now to my astonishment, I learn that the committee proposals have actually become an international standard. Still, I am extremely reluctant to adopt such funny-sounding terms; Jeffrey Harrow says "we're going to have to learn to love (and pronounce)" the new coinages, but he seems to assume that standards are automatically adopted just because they are there.If Gordon Bell and Gene Amdahl used binary sizes -- and they did -- and Knuth thinks the new terms from the pre-existing units sound funny -- and they do -- then I feel like I'm in good company on this one.0: https://honeypot.net/2017/06/11/introducing-metric-quantity....1: https://www-cs-faculty.stanford.edu/~knuth/news99.html
comments.content_cn:
我坚持使用2的幂次方大小。在适当场合为十进制、公制单位创造新词。我提议过[0]“kitribytes”、“metribytes”、“gitribytes”等说法。不能因为“千”在某个语境中有特定含义，就非得在其他地方也沿用这个意思。古希腊人最初用“kilo”时也并非特指“正好一千”。“Giga”原意只是“巨大”，“Tera”不过是“怪物”罢了。国际单位制并没有垄断这些表示“远超我们一眼能数清的数量”的词汇所有权。

唐纳德·克努特本人曾说过[1]：
> 那些委员会的成员提出这个重要议题值得肯定，但当我听到他们的提案时，就觉得它根本行不通——谁会自愿用MiB来表示“可能字节”呢？！所以我提出了上述建议，并在《MMIX导论》第94页提及此事。如今令我惊讶的是，我得知委员会提案竟真的成了国际标准。但我仍然极不情愿采用这些听起来古怪的术语；杰弗里·哈罗说“我们必须学会接受（并读出）这些新造词”，但他似乎认为标准只要存在就会自动被采纳。

既然戈登·贝尔和吉恩·阿姆达尔都使用二进制大小——他们确实这么做了——而且克努特也认为从既有单位衍生出的新术语听起来很滑稽——它们确实如此——那么在这件事上我觉得自己与这些杰出人士志同道合。

0: https://honeypot.net/2017/06/11/introducing-metric-quantity....
1: https://www-cs-faculty.stanford.edu/~knuth/

comments.content: The meaning of kilo, mega, giga, tera, etc. are unambiguous: SI prefixes defined as powers of 10, not 2.  1 TB is 10*12 bytes, not 2*40 bytes.The misuse of those prefixes as powers of 1024, while useful as shorthand for computer memory where binary addressing means, is still exactly that: a misuse of SI prefixes.There's now a separate set of base-2 prefixes to solve this, and people need to update their language accordingly.

comments.content: Final edit:This ambiguity is documented at least back to 1984, by IBM, the pre-eminent computer company of the time.In 1972 IBM started selling the IBM 3333 magnetic disk drive. This product catalog [0] from 1979 shows them marketing the corresponding disks as "100 million bytes" or "200 million bytes" (3336 mdl 1 and 3336 mdl 11, respectively). By 1984, those same disks were marketed in the "IBM Input/Output Device Summary"[1] (which was intended for a customer audience) as "100MB" and "200MB"0: (PDF page 281) "IBM 3330 DISK STORAGE" http://electronicsandbooks.com/edt/manual/Hardware/I/IBM%20w...1: (PDF page 38, labeled page 2-7, Fig 2-4) http://electronicsandbooks.com/edt/manual/Hardware/I/IBM%20w...Also, hats off to http://electronicsandbooks.com/ for keeping such incredible records available for the internet to browse.-------Edit: The below is wrong. Older experience has corrected me - there has always been ambiguity (perhaps bifurcated between CPU/OS and storage domains). "And that with such great confidence!", indeed.-------The article presents wishful thinking. The wish is for "kilobyte" to have one meaning. For the majority of its existence, it had only one meaning - 1024 bytes. Now it has an ambiguous meaning. People wish for an unambiguous term for 1000 bits, however that word does not exist. People also might wish that others use kibibyte any time they reference 1024 bytes, but that is also wishful thinking.The author's wishful thinking is falsely presented as fact.I think kilobyte was the wrong word to ever use for 1024 bytes, and I'd love to go back in time to tell computer scientists that they needed to invent a new prefix to mean "1,024" / "2^10" of something, which kilo- never meant before kilobit / kilobyte were invented. Kibi- is fine, the phonetics sound slightly silly to native English speakers, but the 'bi' indicates binary and I think that's reasonable.I'm just not going to fool myself with wishful thinking. If, in arrogance or self-righteousness, one simply assumes that every time they see "kilobyte" it means 1,000 bytes - then they will make many, many failures. We will always have to take care to verify whether "kilobyte" means 1,000 or 1,024 bytes before implementing something which relies on that for correctness.

comments.author: pjdesno
comments.content: I had a computer architecture prof (a reasonably accomplished one, too) who thought that all CS units should be binary, e.g. Gigabit Ethernet should be 931Mbit/s, not 1000MBit/s.I disagreed strongly - I think X-per-second should be decimal, to correspond to Hertz. But for quantity, binary seems better. (modern CS papers tend to use MiB, GiB etc. as abbreviations for the binary units)Fun fact - for a long time consumer SSDs had roughly 7.37% over-provisioning, because that's what you get when you put X GB (binary) of raw flash into a box, and advertise it as X GB (decimal) of usable storage. (probably a bit less, as a few blocks of the X binary GB of flash would probably be DOA) With TLC, QLC, and SLC-mode caching in modern drives the numbers aren't as simple anymore, though.
comments.content_cn:
我曾有位计算机体系结构教授（也是位相当有成就的学者）认为，所有计算机科学领域的单位都应是二进制制的，例如千兆以太网应该是931兆比特/秒，而非1000兆比特/秒。我强烈反对这一观点——我认为“每秒X单位”应采用十进制，以便与赫兹单位对应。但在表示数量时，二进制似乎更合适。（现代计算机科学论文倾向于使用MiB、GiB等作为二进制单位的缩写）

有趣的是：长期以来消费级固态硬盘普遍存在约7.37%的过量配置，这是因为当你在设备中装入X GB（二进制）原始闪存，却将其宣传为X GB（十进制）可用存储时就会产生这样的差值。（实际可能略低些，因为X二进制GB闪存中可能有部分存储块出厂即损坏）不过在现代硬盘采用TLC、QLC及SLC模式缓存技术后，这些数字关系已不再那么简单了。

comments.author: Out_of_Characte
comments.content:
The author doesn't go far enough into the problems with trying to convert information theory to SI Units.SI units are attempting to fix standard measurements with perceived constants in nature. A meter(Distance) is the distance light travels in a vacuum, back and forth, within a certain amount of ossilations of a cesium atom(Time). This doesn't mean we tweak the meter to conform to observational results as we'd all be happier if light really was 300 000KM/s instead of ~299 792km/s.Then there's the problem of not mixing different measurement units. SI was designed to conform all measurements to the same base 10 exponents (cm, m, km versus feet inches and yards) But the authors attempt to resolve this matter doesn't even conform to standardised SI units as we would expect them to.What is a byte? Well, 8 bits, sometimes.
What is a kilobit? 1000 Bits
What is a kilobyte? 1000 Bytes, or 1024 Bytes.Now we've already mixed units based on what a bit or a byte even is and the addition of the 8 multiplier in addition to the exponent of 1000 or 1024.And if you think, hey, at least the bit is the least divisible unit of information, That's not even correct. If there Should* be a reformalisation of information units, you would agree that the amount of "0"'s is the least divisible unit of information. A kilo of zero's, would be 1000. A 'byte' would be defined as containing up to 256 zero's. A Megazero would contain up to a million zero's.It wouldn't make any intuitive sense for anyone to count 0's, which would automatically convert your information back to base 10, but it does prove that the most sensible unit of information is already what we've had before, that is, you're not mixing bytes (powers of 2) with SI-defined units of 1000
comments.content_cn:
作者在将信息论转换为国际单位制方面探讨得不够深入。国际单位制试图用自然界中感知到的常数来固定标准度量。一米（距离）是光在真空中往返传播的距离，对应铯原子特定次数的振荡（时间）。这并不意味着我们会调整米的定义以符合观测结果——毕竟如果光速真的是30万公里/秒而非约299792公里/秒，大家会更满意。

另一个问题在于不应混用不同的度量单位。国际单位制的设计初衷是将所有度量统一为相同的十进制指数体系（如厘米、米、千米对比英尺、英寸和码）。但作者试图解决这个问题时，甚至未能符合我们预期的标准化国际单位制。

什么是字节？有时是8比特。
什么是千比特？1000比特。
什么是千字节？1000字节或1024字节。

我们已经基于比特或字节的定义混用了单位，同时还在1000或1024的指数基础上增加了8倍乘数。如果你认为比特至少是信息的最小可分单元，这甚至是不正确的。如果信息单位真的需要重新规范，你可能会同意“0”的数量才是信息的最小可分单元。一千个“0”就是1000个零，一个“字节”可定义为最多包含256个零，而“百万零”则最多包含一百万个零。这种设定对任何人来说都缺乏直观意义……

comments.content: > setting weights and measures by local and trade tradition and it was a nightmareAdding to your point, it is human nature to create industry- or context-specific units and refuse to play with others.In the non-metric world, I see examples like: Paper publishing uses points (1/72 inch), metal machinists use thousands of an inch, woodworkers use feet and inches and binary fractions, land surveyors use decimal feet (unusual!), waist circumference is in inches, body height is in feet and inches, but you buy fabric by the yard, airplane altitudes are in hundreds to tens of thousands of feet instead of decimal miles. Crude oil is traded in barrels but gasoline is dispensed in gallons. Everyone thinks their usage of units and numbers is intuitive and optimal, and everyone refuses to change.In the metric(ish) world, I still see many tensions. The micron is a common alternate name for the micrometre, yet why don't we have a millin or nanon or picon? The solution is to eliminate the micron. I've seen the angstrom (0.1 nm) in spectroscopy and in the discussion of CPU transistor sizes, yet it diverts attention away from the picometre. The bar (100 kPa) is popular in talking about things like tire pressure because it's nearly 1 atmosphere. The mmHg is a unit of pressure that sounds metric but is not; the correct unit is pascal. No one in astronomy uses mega/giga/tera/peta/etc.-metres; instead they use AU and parsec and (thousand, million, billion) light-years. Particle physics use eV/keV/MeV instead of some units around the picojoule.Having a grab bag of units and domains that don't talk to each other is indeed the natural state of things. To put your foot down and say no, your industry does not get its own special snowflake unit, stop that nonsense and use the standardized unit - that takes real effort to achieve.

comments.author: soneil
comments.content: It goes back way further than that.  The first IBM harddrive was the IBM 350 for the IBM 305 RAMDAC.  It was 5 million characters. Because humans.Binary addressing made sense for RAM.  Especially since it makes decoding address lines into chip selects (or slabs of core, or whatever) a piece of cake, having chips be a round number in binary made life easier for everyone.Then early DOS systems (CP/M comes to mind particularly) mapped disk sectors to RAM regions, so to enable this shortcut, disk sectors became RAM-shaped.  The 512-byte sector was born.  File sizes can be written in bytes, but what actually matters is how many sectors they take up.  So file sizing inherited this shortcut.But these shortcuts never affected "real computers", only the hamstrung crap people were running at home.So today we have multiple ecosystems.  Some born out of real computers, some with a heavy DOS inheritance.  Some of us were taught DOS's limitations as truth, and some of us weren't.
comments.content_cn:
这要追溯到更早的时候。第一台IBM硬盘是用于IBM 305 RAMDAC的IBM 350。它存储500万个字符——不是字节，当时字节还不是"通用概念"。整整500万字符。最早的硬盘采用的是十进制计数。

我的理论是这样的：最初所有系统都基于十进制，因为人类习惯如此。二进制寻址对内存来说很合理，特别是它能轻松将地址线解码为芯片选择信号（或磁芯存储块等），让芯片数量符合二进制整数规格对所有人都更方便。

后来早期DOS系统（尤其是CP/M）将磁盘扇区映射到内存区域，为了实现这种快捷操作，磁盘扇区开始采用内存的形态。512字节扇区由此诞生。文件大小可以用字节表示，但实际重要的是占用多少扇区。因此文件大小的计算沿用了这种快捷方式。

但这些快捷方式从未影响"真正的计算机"，只限制了家用电脑的功能。所以今天我们存在多种生态系统：有些诞生于真正的计算机，有些则深受DOS传统影响。我们中有些人被灌输DOS的局限性当作真理，有些人则没有。

comments.author: okanat
comments.content: It may "make sense" but that's actually a false equivalence. The raw disk space for a 3.5" high-density floppy disk for IBM PCs is 512 bytes per sector * 18 sectors per track * 80 tracks per side * 2 sides = 1,474,560 bytes. It is 1.47 MB or 1.40 MiB neither of which is 1440 KB or KiB. The 1440 number comes from Microsoft's FAT12 filesystem. That was the space that's left for files outside the allocation table.Sectors per track or tracks per side is subject to change. Moreover a different filesystem may have non-linear growth of the MFT/superblock that'll have a different overhead.https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_floppy_disk_formats

comments.author: icedchai
comments.content:
To add further confusion, 57600 was actually a serial port speed, from the computer to the modem, which was higher than the maximum physical line (modem) speed. Many people ran higher serial port speeds to take advantage of compression (115200 was common.)56000 BPS was the bitrate you could get out of a DS0 channel, which is the digital version of a normal phone line. A DS0 is actually 64000 BPS, but 1 bit out of 8 is "robbed" for overhead/signalling. An analog phone lined got sampled to 56000 BPS, but lines were very noisy, which was fine for voice, but not data.7 bits per sample * 8000 samples per second = 56000, not 57600.
That was theoretical maximum bandwidth! The FCC also capped modems at 53K or something, so you couldn't even get 56000, not even on a good day.
comments.content_cn: 更令人困惑的是，57600实际上是计算机到调制解调器的串口速率，它高于物理线路（调制解调器）的最高速度。许多人使用更高的串口速率以利用压缩技术（115200很常见）。56000比特每秒是DS0通道能够提供的比特率，也就是普通电话线的数字版本。DS0实际上是64000比特每秒，但每8比特中就有1比特被用于开销/信令。模拟电话线被采样为56000比特每秒，但线路噪声很大，这对语音来说没问题，但对数据传输则不行。每个样本7比特乘以每秒8000个样本等于56000，而不是57600。这是理论上的最大带宽！美国联邦通信委员会还将调制解调器速率限制在53K左右，所以即使在理想情况下，你也无法达到56000比特每秒。

posts.title: Agent Skills
posts.author: mooreds
posts.title_cn: 代理技能
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕AI代理技能（Agent Skills）的标准化与实用性展开。核心争议在于技能文件的价值与实现方式。有用户认为，当前技能文件类似于传统文档，其本质仍是清晰易懂的说明，并未改变优质文档的基本原则。也有用户指出，技能的核心价值在于“渐进式披露”，即通过轻量索引让代理按需调用具体指令，从而节省上下文资源。讨论中提到，部分用户将技能视为获取领域内隐性知识的工具，能促使开发者将经验规范化，并可能反馈用于模型训练。  
关于技能的应用场景存在分歧：有人认为通用公共技能集难以奏效，更看好厂商为自身产品或终端用户为个性化需求定制技能；另有观点强调技能应设计为明确、完整的“工作流”而非背景信息，否则代理可能不会主动使用。  
社区普遍认同技能模式能扩展代理能力，类似于“函数库”，但随之带来了供应链安全风险，因为当前技能索引大多未经验证。此外，技能文件的存放路径缺乏统一标准，用户呼吁规范文件夹结构。

comments.author: clarity_hacker
comments.content: The real value isn't the format itself — it's progressive disclosure. When you dump everything into one monolithic doc, you're burning context tokens on instructions the agent doesn't need for the current task.Skills as a pattern let the agent scan a lightweight index of descriptions, then pull in the full instructions only when relevant. Whether that's a .skills/ folder or a README index pointing to separate docs doesn't matter much. What matters is the separation between "what capabilities exist" and "how to execute this specific one."The standardization part is mostly useful for distribution — being able to install and share skills across projects without manually wiring them up. Same reason we standardize package formats even though you could just copy-paste code.
comments.content_cn: 真正的价值不在于格式本身，而在于渐进式呈现。当你把所有内容堆砌在单一文档中时，实际上是在为智能体当前任务并不需要的指令消耗上下文资源。技能作为一种模式，允许智能体先扫描轻量级的描述索引，仅在相关时调取完整指令。无论是采用.skills/文件夹形式，还是通过README索引指向独立文档，这些形式差异并不重要。关键在于区分“存在哪些能力”与“如何执行特定能力”这两个层面。标准化部分的主要价值在于分发——能够跨项目安装和共享技能，而无需手动配置。这正如我们之所以标准化软件包格式，即便直接复制粘贴代码同样可行。

Where does this end? Ordering of skills by specificity, such as org > user > workspace? And we know that skills aren't reliably picked up anyway. And then there's the additional attack surface area for prompt injection.

comments.author: thisisthenewme
comments.content: My unproven theory is that agent skills are just a good way to 'acquire' unspoken domain rules. A lot of things that developers do are just in their heads, and using 'skills' forces them to write these down. Then you feed this back to the LLM company for them to train on.
comments.content_cn: 我未经证实的理论是，代理技能只是一种获取未言明领域规则的好方法。开发者所做的很多事情都只存在于他们的脑海中，而使用“技能”迫使他们将这些内容写下来。然后你将这些反馈给LLM公司供他们训练使用。

comments.author: Soerensen
comments.content: The observation about agents not using skills without being explicitly asked resonates. In practice, I've found success treating skills as explicit "workflows" rather than background context.The pattern that works: skills that represent complete, self-contained sequences - "do X, then Y, then Z, then verify" - with clear trigger conditions. The agent recognizes these as distinct modes of operation rather than optional reference material.What doesn't work: skills as general guidelines or "best practices" documents. These get lost in context or ignored entirely because the agent has no clear signal for when to apply them.The mental model shift: think of skills less like documentation and more like subroutines you'd explicitly invoke. If you wouldn't write a function for it, it probably shouldn't be a skill.
comments.content_cn: 关于智能体不被明确要求就不使用技能的观察确实有共鸣。在实践中，我发现将技能视为明确的“工作流程”而非背景信息更为有效。成功的模式是：将技能设计为完整、自包含的序列——“先做X，再做Y，然后Z，最后验证”——并设定清晰的触发条件。智能体会将这些识别为不同的操作模式，而非可选的参考资料。无效的做法是：将技能作为通用指南或“最佳实践”文档。这些内容往往在上下文中被忽略或完全无视，因为智能体没有明确的信号指示何时应用它们。思维模式的转变是：将技能视为需要明确调用的子程序，而非文档。如果你不会为某个操作编写函数，那它可能也不应成为一个技能。

comments.author: DonHopkins
comments.content: You've nailed the core insight about progressive disclosure. MOOLLM extends this into what we call the Semantic Image Pyramid (or MOO-Maps ;), borrowing from Mip-Maps in graphics. Four resolution levels, each serving different needs.GLANCE.yml is the smallest, 5-70 lines. Just enough to answer "is this relevant?" You can inject all glances into every prompt because they're tiny. The LLM scans them like a table of contents.CARD.yml is the interface layer, 50-200 lines. No implementation, just what the skill offers Capability advertisements, activation conditions, scoring, what it composes with. Think of it like The Sims "advertisement" system or CLOS generic function dispatch. The LLM sniffs this to decide whether to load the full SKILL.md implementation.SKILL.md is the Anthropic-style skill file, 200-1000 lines. The actual instructions, the how. Only loaded when the skill is activated.README.md is the largest, 500+ lines, and it's for humans. History, design rationale, examples. The LLM can dive in when developing the skill or when curious, but it's not burned on every invocation.Reading rule: never load a lower level without first loading the level above. Start with GLANCE, sniff the CARD, load SKILL only if needed.Even more compact than concatenating all glances:We also found INDEX.md beats INDEX.yml for the skill catalog. YAML repeats the same keys for every entry. Markdown allows narrative explanation of how skills relate, which clusters matter for what tasks, making it both more compact and more useful.INDEX.yml: 711 lines, 2061 words, 17509 chars, ~4380 tokens, machine readable structurehttps://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/skills/INDEX.y...INDEX.md: 124 lines, 1134 words, 9487 chars, ~2370 tokens, human readable prosehttps://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/skills/INDEX.m...INDEX.md is 83% fewer lines, 45% fewer words, 46% fewer chars for 121 skills. YAML repeats keys like id, tagline, why for every entry. Markdown uses headers and prose, compresses better, allows narrative grouping of related skills.And it's simply more meaningful to both LLMs and humans, telling a coherent story instead of representing raw data!The Semantic Image Pyramid:https://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/designs/LEELA-...Same principle applies to code. A skill can wrap a sister-script that IS the documentation. A Python script with argparse defines the CLI once, readable by both humans (--help) and LLMs (sniff the top of the python file). No separate docs to maintain, no drift between what the code does and what the docs claim.sister-script: https://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/skills/sister-...Sniffable-python structures code so the API is visible in the first 50 lines. Imports, constants, CLI structure up front. Implementation below the fold. The LLM can decide relevance and understand the API without reading the whole file. Single source of truth, progressive disclosure, don't repeat yourself.sniffable-python README.md: https://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/skills/sniffab...sniffable-python SKILL.md: https://github.com/SimHacker/moollm/blob/main/skills/sniffab...
comments.content_cn:
你精准把握了渐进式披露的核心洞见。MOOLLM将这一理念延伸为我们所称的语义图像金字塔（或称MOO-Maps，借鉴了图形学中的Mip-Maps概念）。它包含四个分辨率层级，各满足不同需求。

GLANCE.yml是最精简的层级，仅5-70行。它刚好能回答“这个内容相关吗？”的问题。由于体积微小，你可以将所有概览文件注入每个提示中。大语言模型会像浏览目录一样扫描它们。

CARD.yml是接口层，约50-200行。它不包含具体实现，仅描述技能提供的功能——能力声明、激活条件、评分标准、可组合对象。这类似于《模拟人生》的“广告”系统或CLOS泛型函数分派机制。大语言模型通过嗅探此层决定是否加载完整的SKILL.md实现文件。

SKILL.md是遵循Anthropic风格的技能文件，约200-1000行。包含实际的操作指南与实现方法，仅在技能激活时加载。

README.md是最大文档（500行以上），面向人类读者。涵盖历史背景、设计原理和用例说明。大语言模型可在开发技能或需要深入理解时查阅，但不会在每次调用时载入。

阅读规则：必须按层级顺序加载，不可跳过上级直接读取下级。从GLANCE开始，嗅探CARD，仅在需要时加载SKILL。

比串联所有概览文件更紧凑的是：
我们还发现对于技能目录，INDEX.md的表现优于INDEX.yml。YAML格式需要为每个条目重复相同键名，而Markdown允许叙述性说明技能间的关联、任务相关的技能集群等重要信息……

It works for everything (including humans!).I wrote a rant about skills a while ago that's still relevant in some ways: https://sibylline.dev/articles/2025-10-20-claude-skills-cons...

comments.author: jgmedr
comments.content: Our team has found success in treating skills more like re-usable semi-deterministic functions and less like fingers-crossed prompts for random edge-cases.For example, we have a skill to /create-new-endpoint. The skill contains a detailed checklist of all the boilerplate tasks that an engineer needs to do in addition to implementing the logic (e.g. update OpenAPI spec, add integration tests, endpoint boilerplate, etc.). The engineer manually invokes the skill from the CLI via slash commands, provides a JIRA ticket number, and engages in some brief design discussion. The LLM is consistently able to one-shot these tickets in a way that matches our existing application architecture.
comments.content_cn: 我们团队成功地将技能更多地视为可重复使用的半确定性函数，而非依赖运气的随机边缘情况提示。例如，我们有一个用于“创建新端点”的技能。该技能包含一份详细的清单，列出了工程师除了实现逻辑外需要完成的所有样板任务（例如更新OpenAPI规范、添加集成测试、端点样板代码等）。工程师通过命令行界面的斜杠命令手动调用该技能，提供JIRA工单号，并进行简短的设计讨论。大型语言模型始终能够一次性处理这些工单，且符合我们现有的应用架构。

comments.author: bob1029
comments.content: I think pre-canned "skills" are an anti-pattern with the frontier models. Arguably, these skills already exist within the LLM. We don't need to explain how to do things they already know how to do.I prefer to completely invert this problem and provoke the model into surfacing whatever desired behavior & capability by having the environment push back on it over time.You get way more interesting behavior from agents when you allow them to probe their environment for a few turns and feed them errors about how their actions are inappropriate. comments.author: empath75
comments.content: They're basically all trade-offs between context-size/token-use and flexibility.  If you can write a bash or a python script, or an api or an MCP to do what you want, then write a bash or python script to do it.  You can even include it in the skill.My general design principle for agents, is that the top level context (ie claude.md, etc) is primarily "information about information", a list of skills, mcps, etc, a very general overview, and a limited amount of information that they always need to have with every request.  Everything more specific is in a skill, which is mostly some very light touch instructions for how to use various tools we have (scripts, apis and mcps).I have found that people very often add _way_ to much information into claude.md's and skills.  Claude knows a lot of stuff already!  Keep your information to things specific whatever you are working on that it doesn't already know.  If your internal processes and house style are super complicated to explain to claude and it keeps making mistakes, you might want to adapt to claude instead of the other way around.  Claude itself makes this mistake!  If you ask it to build a claude md, it'll often fill it with extraneous stuff that it already knows.  You should regularly trim it.
comments.content_cn:
这些本质上都是在上下文大小/令牌使用量与灵活性之间做权衡。如果你能用bash或Python脚本、API或MCP来实现想要的功能，那就直接写脚本处理。你甚至可以把脚本集成到技能里。

我设计智能体的核心原则是：顶层上下文（比如claude.md等文件）主要承载“关于信息的信息”——比如技能列表、MCP配置等概要说明，以及每次请求都必须携带的少量核心信息。所有具体功能都应放在技能中实现，技能文件通常只需简要说明如何使用各类工具（脚本、API和MCP）。

我发现人们经常在claude.md和技能文件里塞进_过量_信息。Claude本身已经具备大量知识！请只提供与你当前工作相关且Claude尚未掌握的具体信息。如果你的内部流程和规范体系向Claude解释起来过于复杂，且它频繁出错，或许你应该调整自身工作方式去适应Claude，而非强求Claude适应你。Claude自身也会犯这种错误——如果你让它生成claude.md文件，它往往会填入大量已知的冗余内容。你需要定期精简这些内容。
