posts.author: davidbarker
posts.title_cn: Xcode 26.3 – 开发者可直接在 Xcode 中调用编程助手
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Xcode 26.3版本引入的AI编程助手功能展开。核心话题是开发者对Xcode集成编码代理（coding agents）功能的评价与期待。有人认为，AI的加入有望简化复杂的Xcode界面，提升开发体验；也有用户指出，Xcode的命令行工具长期存在不可靠、输出冗杂等问题，希望AI能改善底层工具链。讨论中提到，新版本支持MCP协议，允许接入Claude以外的多种代理，这一点受到社区普遍认可，被视为避免厂商锁定的关键。然而，部分用户对实际效果持保留态度，例如有观点认为SwiftUI预览与模拟器交互功能虽值得期待，但基于过往经验，应降低预期。此外，有开发者质疑官方宣传不够清晰，具体更新内容仍需从发布说明中梳理。整体上，社区肯定AI集成的方向，但对实现细节与稳定性存在分歧。

Dennis Ritchie solved this.Why, Apple, in 40 years, could you not ship a lightweight dev-oriented text viewer? You had NeXTSTEP. You had the DNA of the most elegant Unix workstation ever built.And you gave us... this behemoth? An app whose launch time rivals a full Gentoo stage 1 install ( see: https://niden.net/post/gentoo-stage-1-installation )TextEdit is not the answer.I've used Xcode for native iOS development and honestly, once you get past the Stockholm Syndrome phase, it's just fine.- The interface is learnable.- The debugger mostly works.But the load times -- on every high-end MBP I've ever owned -- suggest that somewhere deep in the Xcode binary, there's a sleep(rand()) that someone committed in 2006 and no one has had the courage to git blame.FWIW, I fear someone here tells me I've been missing a launch flag. comments.author: r2vcap
comments.content:
From my years of iOS development—and based on https://xcodereleases.com typically ships two major Xcode updates each year:- X.0 (September): bumps Swift, SDK versions, etc. It also tends to have a noticeably longer beta cycle than other releases.
- X.3 or X.4 (around March): bumps Swift again and raises the minimum required macOS version.Other releases in between are usually smaller updates that add features or fix bugs, but they don’t involve major toolchain-level or fundamental changes.Today’s release doesn’t bump the Swift version, which suggests the core toolchain is essentially the same as Xcode 26.2—so it makes sense that the minimum macOS version wasn’t raised either.
comments.content_cn:
根据我多年的iOS开发经验，并参考https://xcodereleases.com的信息，Xcode通常每年发布两次重大更新：
- X.0版本（9月）：更新Swift和SDK版本等。与其他版本相比，其测试周期往往明显更长。
- X.3或X.4版本（约3月）：再次更新Swift并提高最低macOS系统要求。
期间的其他版本通常是添加功能或修复漏洞的小幅更新，不涉及工具链层面或基础性的重大变更。
今日发布的版本未更新Swift版本，这表明其核心工具链与Xcode 26.2基本相同——因此未提高最低macOS系统要求也在情理之中。

comments.content: Like you, I think that Xcode maybe gets a worse rap than it deserves, but it's also endlessly frustrating.First, the performance is just bad. The responsiveness compared to apps like VSC or Panic’s Nova is night-and-day.The attention given to the design of new features is piss-poor. Placing the AI functionality on the left sidebar makes no sense; all the other tools on the left are project management; the "let me run weird functions and interact with stuff" UIs like terminal, debug and logs are in the bottom panel. Or maybe a new tab in the main workspace area?The SwiftUI preview canvas can't be floated as a separate window, making it all but useless on anything smaller than a 16" MBP (and only barely usable there). In fact, I think it might be impossible to use Xcode in multiple screens altogether…?Old simulator versions and cache files hang around forever, you need a third-party app like DevCleaner just to keep your storage from filling with nonsense. Cryptic messages like "copying symbols to device"… clear-cache that doesn't seem to clear-cache, that stupid list UI for info.plist…I never thought I'd have anything nice to say about PNPM package management, but you can always just delete `node_modules` and reinstall and count on things working. Swift package management is a cryptic mess, and their insistence on using a GUI instead of a basic JSON manifest just compounds it. Like the info.plist thing, a lot of Xcode is based on a developer UI philosophy from the Mac Classic days that has mostly been abandoned by the rest of the world.Mostly, I think the vitriol surrounding Xcode is that Apple seems to think they're doing a good job; meanwhile their most ardent and adept users are insisting that they are not. Same boat as MacOS, really.

posts.title: See how many words you have written in Hacker News comments
posts.author: Imustaskforhelp
posts.title_cn: 查看你在Hacker News评论中写了多少字
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕一个统计用户在Hacker News评论总字数的工具展开。核心话题是用户对自身及社区成员评论量的数据反馈与相关功能探讨。

多数用户对工具表示兴趣，有人惊喜于自己的排名（如用户4、7、9），也有用户指出数据异常：用户5发现高karma用户ingve字数极少，质疑统计逻辑；用户1和9提到搜索框区分大小写带来不便。讨论中形成部分共识，如用户普遍关注字数与karma值的关系，用户6建议计算“每字karma密度”以衡量表达效率。

分歧主要体现在数据解读上：有人认为字数反映参与度（如用户3计算日均写作量），也有用户指出字数与影响力不成正比（如用户5列举的案例）。此外，用户2怀念已离开的活跃用户，用户10对陌生高排名用户表示疑惑，侧面反映社区成员对互动质量的关注。工具还引发延伸讨论，如用户8提议增加阅读统计功能。

comments.author: troad
comments.content: The irony is that karma posts are so easy. Take something most of your audience already agrees with, triple down on some reductionist caricature of it, and smother it in pithy glibness. The shorter the better. Particularly effective if you set up a false dichotomy vis-a-vis the person you're replying to. It's a reflexive style of engagement for many, and HN is not immune to it.I aim to avoid it these days, with varying degrees of success. I don't need fictitious internet points, I want to hear other people's genuine thoughts on a subject of interest. Or sometimes just to share something I thought was neat.But since all social media are Pavlovian conditioning for points, you rarely get any fruitful exchange. And it seems to be getting rarer and rarer, sadly.I wonder how one would structure social media to avoid it. HN is good, but the karma system is a double edged sword. Would it increase the quality of the discussion to retain the use of points for ranking posts, but hide point counts completely? Perhaps they could be represented by words: "Positive response", "negative response", but only past -3 and +3, with no changes in wording beyond that score?

但由于所有社交媒体都在用积分制造巴甫洛夫式条件反射，富有成效的交流日渐稀少，这实在令人遗憾。我常思考如何设计社交媒体才能规避这种弊端。Hacker News 本是不错的平台，但积分系统犹如双刃剑。如果保留积分排序功能但完全隐藏具体数值，能否提升讨论质量？或许可以用文字替代数字："积极反馈"、"消极反馈"，且仅在正负三分阈值外显示，超过该分值后不再变更表述方式？

posts.title: Anki ownership transferred to AnkiHub
posts.author: trms
posts.title_cn: Anki所有权已转移至AnkiHub
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕知名开源记忆卡片软件Anki的所有权转移至AnkiHub公司一事展开。核心话题是用户对这一变更可能带来的影响，尤其是对软件开源性和未来发展方向的担忧与期待。

多数用户对原开发者Damien多年贡献表示感谢，并肯定Anki对其学习的重要帮助。社区普遍希望Anki能保持开源，并期待此次转移能推动软件更新，例如改进用户体验和用更先进的FSRS算法替代老旧的SM2算法。

但观点存在明显分歧。有人认为商业力量的介入可能带来积极共生关系，只要各方谨慎行事、坚守开源原则；也有用户指出AnkiHub过往有将免费社区项目商业化的行为，对其领导风格和动机表示不信任，担心软件会走向封闭或付费墙模式。讨论中提到，部分用户因此感到忧虑，但同时也相信即使情况恶化，强大的社区仍有能力分叉并维护一个开源版本。

More than just memorizing kanji on AnkiDroid during my commute, I just started to believe I could learn anything.  I was starting to take my coding hobby more seriously at the time and hacking on Anki was a big part of that too.  Thanks for all the hard work Damien and David Allison. comments.author: Ajedi32
comments.content: Always a bit scary when an open source project changes stewardship like this, but I'm quite relieved to see all involved parties seem to be aware of the dangers and very much on the same page about not screwing this up.Done right, commercial interests can often have a very positive symbiotic relationship with open source. Almost all the largest and best open source projects out there have substantial involvement from commercial interests.I do think though that from a structural/governance perspective it's not a good idea for Anki to be owned by AnkiHub. Anki is a community project, not a corporate product, and while it sounds like the license will continue to reflect that, I personally think it would be best if the corporate structure did too. If Anki were spun out as an independent foundation (like Blender, Linux, etc) receiving most of its support and development work from AnkiHub, rather than owned outright, I think that would allow a much more robust governance structure than just having everything be under AnkiHub's direct control with some pinky promises about listening to the community.
comments.content_cn:
每当开源项目更换管理者时，总会让人有些担忧，但看到所有相关方似乎都意识到了潜在风险，并且对于如何避免搞砸这件事达成了高度共识，这让我相当放心。如果处理得当，商业利益往往能与开源形成非常积极的共生关系。几乎所有规模最大、质量最优的开源项目背后都有商业力量的深度参与。

不过从组织结构与治理角度来看，我认为由AnkiHub完全持有Anki的所有权并非良策。Anki本质上是社区项目而非企业产品，虽然相关许可协议似乎会继续保持这一特性，但我个人认为其公司架构也应体现这一原则。倘若将Anki独立设置为非营利基金会（如同Blender、Linux等项目的模式），主要接受AnkiHub的支持与开发贡献，而非被其完全持有，这样的治理结构将比单纯依靠AnkiHub在直接控制下做出倾听社区的承诺要稳固得多。

As well as saving and preserving all of the decks there, as they are sure to go behind a paywall.I, and I am sure many other HNers, would be willing to support that with our time and financially.[0] https://www.ankihub.net/about-us

comments.content_cn:
当一个由单人开发者主导的流行、免费且开源的激情项目，转手给一家需要维持30人团队的公司时，接下来会发生什么不言而喻。AnkiHub的一贯做法是接管那些进行自由交流的社区或项目，并将其货币化或设置付费门槛。如果你曾是/r/medicalschoolanki子论坛的一员，你完全明白我的意思。那个社区已被彻底掏空。

在帖子中，AnkiHub提到Anki对他们而言是多么“神圣”。然而，他们却毫无顾忌地将自己嵌入Anki的设置菜单，成为有史以来唯一这样做的第三方。我确信更多类似举动还会接踵而至。而且他们帖子中使用的措辞几乎从未有助于他们的立场，尤其是在定价和开源软件部分。

我理解为什么Damien觉得他成了Anki发展的瓶颈。这与Bram和Vim的情况类似。最终，社区分叉并创建了Neovim。Gorhill也曾类似地转让了uBlock，但后来又回归并开发了uBlock Origin。因此，由社区或领导者主导的成功分支已有先例可循。

同步功能肯定会变成付费服务，共享牌组的访问权限也不例外。

创建一个指向托管版同步服务器的分支，以及一个替代中心让人们可以分享除AnkiWeb之外的牌组至关重要。同时，保存并备份那里的所有牌组也同样重要，因为它们注定会被置于付费墙之后。

我相信包括我在内的许多其他HN用户，都愿意支持这样的举措……

comments.author: zelphirkalt
comments.content: I think many learners are walking into a trap of thinking, if they just change their SPS algorithm, they will magically learn more. It is good to be able to practice known words less often, obviously, but that can be achieved using a very basic system already.If changing their SPS or the promises about an SPS motivate the learner, then great, they're putting in the work and time to learn, but I doubt that the effect of changing the SPS is as large as some people claim.For example I used a tool that supposedly uses FSPS, but it did have a low maximum for the duration you don't have to practice a word, and no way for me to "ban" a word, so that it asks me in 6 months or something, and simple words kept coming back, especially after not learning for a few days. I didn't make much progress using the tool, even though it had FSPS.

posts.title: What's up with all those equals signs anyway?
posts.author: todsacerdoti
posts.title_cn: "这些等号到底是怎么回事？"
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕电子邮件中大量等号（=）出现的原因展开。核心话题是解释这些等号源于电子邮件编码标准“quoted-printable”，用于在纯文本传输中表示特殊字符。讨论中提到，许多用户原本对邮件中频繁出现的“=20”等符号感到困惑。

有人认为，等号的出现往往伴随着相邻字母的缺失，这类似于编程中的“差一错误”，表明解码处理不当。也有用户指出，问题根源在于处理者具备一定知识，知道邮件非纯文本，却错误地手动进行查找替换解码，而非使用标准解码库，这属于“一知半解反而更危险”的典型情况。

社区普遍认同电子邮件系统看似简单，实际因历史遗留和边缘情况而异常复杂，处理邮件解析需要专业经验。分歧点在于部分用户更关注技术细节与解码机制，而另一些用户则从事件背景（如爱泼斯坦文件披露）或个人经验（如自行开发邮件归档软件遇到的挑战）角度参与讨论。整体上，讨论揭示了电子邮件底层编码的隐蔽性及其容易误处理的特点。

RFC 821 finally limited the line length to at most 1000 bytes.Given a mechanism for soft line breaks, breaking already at below 80 characters would increase compatibility with older mail software and be more convenient when listing the raw email in a terminal.This is also why MIME Base64 typically inserts line breaks after 76 characters.
comments.content_cn: 邮件（或曾经）是逐行处理的，通常使用固定长度的缓冲区。这避免了动态内存分配和编写流式解析器的需要。RFC 821最终将行长度限制在最多1000字节。考虑到软换行机制，在低于80个字符处换行将提高与旧版邮件软件的兼容性，并在终端中列出原始邮件时更加方便。这也是为什么MIME Base64通常在76个字符后插入换行符。

The collected mass of mangled junk is then shipped to whoever, either in boxes or on CD-ROM/DVD (yes, still) or something. Their instinct is not to bring in a bunch of clever folk that might make the work product come out better, because "better" for them is different than "better" for Twitter or Facebook. posts.author: GalaxySnail
posts.title_cn: Floppinux – 单软盘嵌入式 Linux，2025 年版
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了2025年版的Floppinux项目，这是一个可运行在单张软盘上的嵌入式Linux系统。核心话题围绕在复古硬件上运行极简Linux的可行性与技术挑战。

社区讨论中，许多用户分享了在老旧硬件（如386、486）上运行Linux的经验。有人认为老旧计算机的性能对于基础生产力任务已足够，主要瓶颈在于现代浏览器软件。也有用户指出寻找能在低配置硬件（如8MB内存的386）上运行的Linux发行版很困难，目前仅ELKS等非标准Linux能运行。

讨论中提到，部分用户曾成功用软盘系统（如floppyfw、CoyoteLinux）将老旧PC改造成路由器，运行稳定。但有用户反映Floppinux在实际486机器上无法启动，即使满足内存要求。技术层面，有用户探讨了是否必须格式化软盘、能否通过内核直接加载等优化方案。

普遍认同的看法包括：软盘系统在特定历史时期具有实用价值，且其启动过程带给用户独特的期待感。分歧点主要在于具体技术实现方式，以及不同硬件配置下的兼容性问题。

comments.author: sockbot
comments.content: Over Christmas I tried to actually build a usable computer from the 32-bit era. Eventually I discovered that the problem isn't really the power of the computer. Computers have been powerful enough for productivity tasks for 20 years, excepting browser-based software.The two main problems I ran into were 1) software support at the application layer, and 2) video driver support. There is a herculean effort on the part of package maintainers to build software for distros, and no one has been building 32 bit version of software for years, even if it is possible to build from source. There is only a very limited set of software you can use, even CLI software because so many things are built with 64 bit dependencies. Secondly, old video card drivers are being dropped from the kernel. This means all you have is basic VGA "safe-mode" level support, which isn't even fast enough to play an MPEG2. My final try was to install Debian 5, which was period correct and had support for my hardware, but the live CDs of the the time were not hybrid so the ISO could not boot from USB. I didn't have a burner so I finally gave up.So I think these types of projects are fun for a proof of concept, but unfortunately are never going to give life to old computers.
comments.content_cn: 圣诞节期间，我尝试组装一台真正可用的32位时代电脑。最终发现问题的核心并非计算机性能——实际上近20年来，除浏览器软件外，计算机处理生产力任务的能力早已足够。我遇到的两个主要障碍是：1）应用层软件支持，2）显卡驱动支持。软件包维护者虽为发行版构建软件付出巨大努力，但多年来已无人开发32位版本，即便从源码编译理论上可行。受限于大量依赖64位架构的组件，实际可用软件范围极其有限，甚至命令行工具也受影响。其次，旧款显卡驱动正被内核逐步淘汰，这意味着只能获得基础的VGA"安全模式"级别支持，其性能甚至不足以流畅播放MPEG2视频。最后我尝试安装年代匹配且支持硬件的Debian5系统，但当时的LiveCD并非混合制式导致ISO无法从USB启动。由于没有光驱，最终只能放弃。这类概念验证项目虽然有趣，但恐怕难以真正让旧电脑重获新生。

comments.author: st_goliath
comments.content: Have you tested this on an actual 486?Sadly, it does not seem to boot on my 486 DX2, I even stuffed 32M of RAM into the machine (8*4M, maximum the mainboard supports), more than the recommended 20M.I have copied the floppy image from the site. It churns for about a minute and a half, loading kernel and initrd, then says "Booting kernel failed: Invalid Argument" and drops into SYSLINUX prompt.EDIT: I tried a few more floppies to rule that out as the cause of the problem.Here are some screenshots: https://imgur.com/a/floppinux-0-3-1-Mdh1c0wEDIT 2: I cloned SYSLINUX, checked out the specific commit and did some prodding around.The function `bios_boot_linux` in `com32/lib/syslinux/load_linux.c` initializes errno to EINVAL. Besides sanity checking the header of the kernel image, there are a few other error paths that also `goto bail;` without changing errno.Those other error paths all seem to be related to handling the memory map. I know that the BIOS in my machine does not support the E820h routine. I have a hunch that this might be the reason why it fails.The website has an image gallery where people ran it on actual hardware: https://krzysztofjankowski.com/floppinux/floppinux-in-the-wi...Most of those machines seem to be newer systems which probably support E820h, except for another 486 DX2 with a similar vintage as mine, that also failed to boot.
comments.content_cn: 你是否在真实的486机器上测试过这个？遗憾的是，它似乎无法在我的486 DX2上启动，我甚至给机器装了32M内存（8*4M，主板支持的最大值），超过了推荐的20M。我从网站复制了软盘镜像。它运行了大约一分半钟，加载内核和initrd，然后显示“启动内核失败：无效参数”并跳转到SYSLINUX提示符。编辑：我尝试了更多软盘以排除这是问题的原因。以下是一些截图：https://imgur.com/a/floppinux-0-3-1-Mdh1c0w编辑2：我克隆了SYSLINUX，检出特定提交并进行了一些探查。`com32/lib/syslinux/load_linux.c`中的函数`bios_boot_linux`将errno初始化为EINVAL。除了对内核镜像头部进行完整性检查外，还有其他一些错误路径也会`goto bail;`而不改变errno。这些其他错误路径似乎都与处理内存映射有关。我知道我机器中的BIOS不支持E820h例程。我直觉认为这可能是它失败的原因。网站上有一个图库，显示人们在真实硬件上运行它：https://krzysztofjankowski.com/floppinux/floppinux-in-the-wi...这些机器大多数似乎是较新的系统，可能支持E820h，除了另一台与我年代相似的486 DX2，也未能启动。

comments.content: I wonder if formatting the floppy is necessary. I know u-boot can do it, but that's 8+ MB.As an alternative, isn't ext2 smaller by having no FAT tables?

comments.author: mlacks
comments.content: Reminds me of my first linux distro called damnsmall linux. I think this was used as a first attempt to port linux to the gamecube, but the main team driving the effort ended up going with Gentoo instead.From the main page:As with most things in the GNU/Linux community, this project continues to stand on the shoulders of giants. I am just one guy without a CS degree, so for now, this project is based on antiX 23 i386. AntiX is a fantastic distribution that I think shares much of the same spirit as the original DSL project. AntiX shares pedigree with MEPIS and also leans heavily on the geniuses at Debian. So, this project stands on the shoulders of giants. In other words, DSL 2024 is a humble little project!Though it may seem comparably ridiculous that 700MB is small in 2024 when DSL was 50MB in 2002, I’ve done a lot of hunting to find small footprint applications, and I had to do some tricks to get a workable desktop into the 700MB limit. To get the size down the ISO currently reduced full language support for German, English, French, Spanish, Portuguese and Brazilian Portuguese (de_DE, en_AU, en_GB, en_US, es_ES, fr_FR, es_ES, pt_PT, & pt_BR ). I had to strip the source codes, many man pages, and documentation out. I do provide a download script that will restore all the missing files, and so far, it seems to be working well.https://www.damnsmalllinux.org/
comments.content_cn:
这让我想起了我的第一个Linux发行版Damn Small Linux。我记得它最初是尝试将Linux移植到GameCube上的首次努力，但主导该项目的团队最终选择了Gentoo。从主页来看：正如GNU/Linux社区中的大多数项目一样，这个项目也是站在巨人的肩膀上。我只是一个没有计算机科学学位的人，因此目前这个项目基于antiX 23 i386。AntiX是一个很棒的发行版，我认为它与原版DSL项目有着许多共同的精神。AntiX与MEPIS一脉相承，并且也极大地依赖于Debian的天才们。所以，这个项目同样是站在巨人的肩膀上。换句话说，DSL 2024是一个谦逊的小项目！

尽管在2024年看来，700MB的体积相比2002年DSL的50MB可能显得颇为可笑，但我花了大量精力寻找占用空间小的应用程序，并且不得不使用一些技巧才能在700MB的限制内构建出一个可用的桌面环境。为了缩小体积，目前的ISO镜像已减少了对德语、英语、法语、西班牙语、葡萄牙语和巴西葡萄牙语（de_DE、en_AU、en_GB、en_US、es_ES、fr_FR、es_ES、pt_PT和pt_BR）的完整语言支持。我还不得不移除源代码、许多手册页和文档。但我提供了一个下载脚本，可以恢复所有缺失的文件，目前看来效果良好。

comments.author: Fiveplus
comments.content: The persistence strategy described here (mount -t msdos -o rw /dev/fd0 /mnt) combined with a bind mount to home is a nice clever touch for saving space.I don't know if that's also true for data integrity on physical magnetic media. FAT12 is not a journaling filesystem. On a modern drive, a crash during a write is at best, annoying while on a 3.5" floppy with a 33mhz CPU, a write operation blocks for a perceptible amount of time. If the user hits the power switch or the kernel panics while the heads are moving or the FAT is updating, that disk is gone. The article mentions sync, but sync on a floppy drive is an agonizingly slow operation that users might interrupt.Given the 253KiB free space constraint, I wonder if a better approach would be treating the free space as a raw block device or a tiny appended partition using a log-structured filesystem designed for slow media (like a stripped down JFFS2 or something), though that might require too many kernel modules.Has anyone out there experimented with appending a tar archive to the end of the initramfs image inplace for persistence, rather than mounting the raw FAT filesystem? It might be safer to serialize writes only on shutdown, would love more thoughts on this.
comments.content_cn: 这里描述的持久化策略（通过mount -t msdos -o rw /dev/fd0 /mnt命令挂载并结合绑定挂载到home目录）在节省空间方面是个巧妙的设计。但我不确定这种策略对于物理磁性介质的数据完整性是否同样有效。FAT12并非日志型文件系统。在现代硬盘上，写入过程中发生崩溃顶多令人烦恼；而在使用33MHz CPU的3.5英寸软盘上，写入操作会阻塞相当长的时间。如果用户在磁头移动或FAT表更新时切断电源或内核崩溃，那张磁盘就报废了。文章提到了sync命令，但在软盘驱动器上执行sync是极其缓慢的操作，用户可能会中断该过程。考虑到253KiB的可用空间限制，我在想是否更好的方法是将空闲空间视为原始块设备，或是使用专为慢速介质设计的日志结构文件系统（例如精简版JFFS2之类）创建微型附加分区，但这可能需要加载过多内核模块。有没有人尝试过在initramfs镜像末尾直接附加tar归档文件来实现持久化，而不是挂载原始的FAT文件系统？仅在关机时序列化写入操作可能更安全，期待更多关于这个思路的讨论。

comments.author: dspillett
comments.content: > There is 264KB of space left for your newly created files.This could be increased noticeably by using one of the common extended floppy formats. The 21-sectors-per-track format used by MS¹ for Windows 95's floppy distribution was widely supported enough by drives (and found to be reliable enough on standard disks) that they considered it safe for mass use, and gave 1680KB instead of the 1440Kb offered by the standard 18-sector layout. The standard floppy formatting tools for Linux support creating such layouts.--------[1] There was some suggestion² that MS invented the extended floppy format, they were sometimes called “windows format”, but it³ had been used elsewhere for some time before MS used them for Windows and Office.[2] I'm not sure if this came from MS themselves, or was invented by the tech press.[3] and even further extended formats, including 1720KByte by squeezing in two extra tracks as well as more data per track which IIRC was used for OS/2 install floppies.
comments.content_cn:
您新创建的文件仅剩264KB空间。若采用常见的扩展软盘格式，空间可显著增加。微软为Windows 95软盘分发采用的每磁道21扇区格式，因其在驱动器上的广泛兼容性（且在标准磁盘上足够可靠），被认定为适合大规模使用，可提供1680KB容量，远超标准18扇区布局的1440KB。Linux的标准软盘格式化工具支持创建此类布局。

注1：曾有观点称扩展软盘格式由微软首创（有时被称为“Windows格式”），但实际上该格式在微软将其用于Windows和Office之前，早已在其他领域应用多时。

注2：不确定此说法源自微软官方还是科技媒体的杜撰。

注3：甚至存在进一步扩展的格式，例如通过增加两个额外磁道及提升每磁道数据密度实现1720KB容量——据回忆，该格式曾用于OS/2系统的安装软盘。

comments.author: M95D
comments.content:
FAT can be made tolerant form the driver just like a journaled FS:  1) mark blocks allocated in first FAT
  If a crash occurs here, then data written is incomplete, so write FAT1 with data from FAT2 discarding all changes.
  
  2) write data in sectors
  If a crash occurs here, same as before, keep old file size.
  
  3) update file size in the directory
  This step is atomic - it's just one sector to update. If a crash occurs here (file size matches FAT1), copy FAT1 to FAT2 and keep the new file size.
  
  4) mark blocks allocated in the second FAT
  If a crash occurs here, write is complete, just calculate and update free space.
  
  5) update free space
comments.content_cn:
FAT文件系统可以通过驱动程序实现类似日志文件系统的容错机制：
1) 在第一份FAT中标记已分配的块
   若此时发生崩溃，已写入数据不完整，则用FAT2的数据覆盖FAT1，丢弃所有更改。

2) 在扇区中写入数据
   若此时发生崩溃，处理方式同前，保持原有文件大小。

3) 在目录中更新文件大小
   此步骤具有原子性——仅需更新单个扇区。若此时发生崩溃（文件大小与FAT1匹配），则将FAT1复制到FAT2并保留新文件大小。

4) 在第二份FAT中标记已分配的块
   若此时发生崩溃，写入操作已完成，只需计算并更新空闲空间。

5) 更新空闲空间

posts.title: Lessons learned shipping 500 units of my first hardware product
posts.author: sberens
posts.title_cn: 首批500件硬件产品出货的经验教训
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了硬件初创者首次量产500件产品的经验教训。核心话题围绕硬件制造中的供应链管理、质量控制以及创业挑战展开。

讨论中提到，用户普遍认同中国供应链在成本控制上的极致追求，有评论指出“任何未明确指定的细节都会以最低成本方式处理”。也有用户对产品光谱测量的准确性提出疑问，希望看到具体数据支持“模拟太阳光谱”的宣传。关于投资逻辑，有人认为SaaS投资者往往不理解硬件创业的商业模式差异。

分歧点主要体现在产品设计细节上：有用户赞赏灯具的独特设计和高亮度，但也指出主动风扇冷却方案存在缺陷；另有用户询问能否实现更低亮度调节以适应夜间使用场景。对于制造失误的责任归属，社区关注工厂沟通错误导致的模具修改成本由谁承担。

帖子作者积极参与答疑，社区对这类实践分享型内容表示欢迎，认为比纯理论讨论更有价值。整体讨论呈现硬件创业者面临的实际挑战与不同专业背景读者的多元视角。

comments.author: ggm
comments.content: This is the second article about hardware supply from China I've read and it reads very much the same, albiet in a different niche (the other one was about SBC construction) -Anything you don't specify will be done least cost, and there is no amount of "least" which cannot be chased in manufacture.The other one noted if you don't specify the density of plastic for bags, or paper for bags and packing, you get clingfilm thinner than you thought existed, and paper which is almost tissue in its weakness. You don't even get boxes to put the boxes in, if you don't specify boxes to be delivered in boxes. So now wrapping a pallet becomes a nightmare if they don't stack. And if you don't specify how many to stack, and how to pad the stack, they won't do unit height stacking if it costs labour time. Your risk.Some of this like the casting mistake, or the knob thing, could happen anywhere and you have to be close to final manufacture spec to find out e.g. the metal coating impinges on the knob at the free space you specified, because your test rig didn't have powder coating. Or, that a design feature you need like the light entry holes, is used by the casting engineer as pour points because it looked like you'd specified mould pour points not functional holes.But other things like "yea, you didn't spec how long to make the tails so we cut the tails as close as we could" is just the cheapening above: if you don't SAY its a 10cm tail for the connector, it will be 2cm, if saving 8cm of cable saves money for them.I've read some stuff which says the cost of 5 SBC boards with pre-applied SMD is now so low, you might as well order 5 so you get at least 1 which works. That means they will wind up working out your tolerance for failure, and produce goods to meet that: if 1 in 5 is viable, thats what they'll target.
comments.content_cn:
这是我读到的第二篇关于中国硬件供应的文章，内容大同小异，只是领域不同（另一篇是关于单板机结构的）——任何你没有明确指定的部分，都会以最低成本的方式完成，而且在制造过程中，没有最低成本是不能追求的。另一篇文章提到，如果你没有规定包装袋塑料的密度，或者包装袋和填充纸的纸质，你就会得到比你想象中还要薄的保鲜膜，以及脆弱得几乎像纸巾一样的纸张。如果你没有明确要求箱子要用箱子装运，你甚至得不到用来装箱子的外箱。所以现在如果箱子不能堆叠，托盘包装就会变成一场噩梦。如果你没有规定堆叠的数量和垫料方式，他们就不会进行单元高度堆叠，因为这需要额外的人工时间。风险由你承担。

其中一些问题，比如铸造错误或旋钮问题，在任何地方都可能发生，你必须接近最终制造规格才能发现，例如金属涂层侵蚀了你指定的自由空间内的旋钮，因为你的测试设备没有粉末涂层。或者，你需要的设计特征，比如进光孔，被铸造工程师用作浇注点，因为它看起来像是你指定的模具浇注点而不是功能孔。

但其他事情，比如“是的，你没有规定线尾要多长，所以我们尽可能剪短了线尾”，这只是上述降低成本的表现：如果你没有说明连接器需要10厘米的线尾，它就会是2厘米，这样可以节省8厘米的线材……

comments.author: syntaxing
comments.content: As a MechE turned SWE, always a fun read when SWE try hardware.> Blink and you’ll get a different measurement.This means your environment is not controlled enough. Also quality control is usually done in terms of statistics. You might want to read something called gauge R&R. That being said, you should be proud of being able to ship a physical product!As for quality checks, software quality teams pales in comparison to hardware quality teams. Mainly as you said, there’s a lot checks you can do in software. For hardware, bigger companies have to have their vendors qualified. The vendors have to follow their customer guidelines and do outgoing inspection. Then the company has a division to do incoming inspection. There’s a traveler that follows the kit (of parts) and there’s usually subassembly quality checks. Then final full build checks before it leaves the door.
comments.content_cn: 作为一名从机械工程师转行的软件工程师，看到软件工程师尝试硬件总是很有趣。> 眨眼间测量结果就变了。这说明你的环境控制得不够好。而且质量控制通常是通过统计方法进行的。你可能需要了解一下测量系统分析（GR&R）。话虽如此，能够交付实体产品还是值得骄傲的！至于质量检查，软件质量团队与硬件质量团队相比就相形见绌了。主要是如你所说，软件可以做很多检查。对于硬件，大公司必须对其供应商进行资质认证。供应商必须遵循客户指导方针并进行出厂检验。然后公司有专门的部门进行来料检验。每个零件包都有随行流程单，通常还有子装配质量检查。最后在出厂前进行完整的最终装配检查。

posts.title: 221 Cannon is Not For Sale
posts.author: mecredis
posts.title_cn: "221 加农炮" 非卖品
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子围绕“房产欺诈”这一核心话题展开讨论，标题“221 Cannon is Not For Sale”暗示了虚假房产出售广告的案例。讨论中，用户们分享了不同国家类似诈骗的经历，包括美国、英国、印度等地出现的伪造房产信息、冒名出售等事件。

社区观点呈现分歧。部分用户对执法效率表示不满，例如有用户指出FBI等机构对此类犯罪应对不力；也有用户强调个人需主动防范，建议通过土地登记警报或设置法律留置权来保护产权。讨论中提到，一些用户对原作者“多数人身份被盗过”的表述提出质疑，认为其夸大了普遍性。

共识在于，房产欺诈是一个跨国存在的严重问题，且平台（如Facebook）对虚假广告的移除机制常被批评为无效。整体上，用户普遍认同需提高警惕并寻求法律与技术手段结合的自保措施。

posts.title: Anthropic is Down
posts.author: ersiees
posts.title_cn: Anthropic服务中断
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Anthropic公司旗下AI服务Claude的宕机事件展开。用户普遍反映Claude服务不稳定，频繁出现错误和响应缓慢问题，甚至有用户对比指出其宕机频率高于OpenAI和Google的同类服务。部分用户认为大语言模型已趋于同质化，切换成本很低，宕机时可轻松改用其他工具；也有用户指出Claude尽管在编程方面表现优秀，但客户端体验差、存在随机限制，基础设施显得脆弱。讨论中提到，有用户建议可借机尝试本地模型替代方案，还有Anthropic可靠性团队成员出面道歉并承诺进行复盘。共识在于Claude的服务稳定性亟待改进，分歧则体现在对宕机影响的容忍度不同：有人认为这只是轻微不便，也有工程师用户强烈批评其可靠性问题。

comments.content_cn: 大型语言模型逐渐商品化的好处在于切换成本极低。我通过VS Code扩展使用Claude Code，刚才遇到几次500错误时，只需将最后指令复制粘贴到Codex就能继续工作。在科技领域，切换成本如此之低的情况实在罕见！

posts.title: 4x faster network file sync with rclone (vs rsync) (2025)
posts.author: indigodaddy
posts.title_cn: 使用rclone实现网络文件同步速度提升4倍（对比rsync）（2025年）
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕rclone与rsync在文件同步性能上的对比展开。核心话题是rclone通过多线程并行传输实现比rsync更快的网络文件同步速度，但社区对此存在不同看法。

有人认为rclone的并行流传输确实能提升速度，尤其适用于高速网络环境或存在硬件瓶颈的场景。也有用户指出，rsync本身可通过脚本实现并行传输，且其增量同步和硬链接处理能力在节省带宽方面具有优势，配合SSH协议更灵活通用。讨论中提到，部分用户肯定rclone的实用性，甚至基于它开发了云存储迁移服务，但另一些用户抱怨其在某些云平台（如Google Photos）的兼容性下降或配置复杂。

分歧主要在于工具选择：一方更看重传输速度，另一方则强调带宽效率与跨平台可靠性。共识在于，两者各有适用场景，用户需根据具体需求（如数据量、网络条件、功能侧重）进行选择。

comments.author: digiown
comments.content: Note there is no intrinsic reason running multiple streams should be faster than one [EDIT: "at this scale"]. It almost always indicates some bottleneck in the application or TCP tuning. (Though, very fast links can overwhelm slow hardware, and ISPs might do some traffic shaping too, but this doesn't apply to local links).SSH was never really meant to be a high performance data transfer tool, and it shows. For example, it has a hardcoded maximum receive buffer of 2MiB (separate from the TCP one), which drastically limits transfer speed over high BDP links (even a fast local link, like the 10gbps one the author has). The encryption can also be a bottleneck. hpn-ssh [1] aims to solve this issue but I'm not so sure about running an ssh fork on important systems.1. https://github.com/rapier1/hpn-ssh
comments.content_cn: 请注意，运行多个流本质上并不比单个流更快[编辑："在此规模下"]。这几乎总是表明应用程序或TCP调优存在某种瓶颈。（不过，极快的链路可能压垮慢速硬件，互联网服务提供商也可能进行流量整形，但这不适用于本地链路）。SSH从未真正被设计为高性能数据传输工具，这一点显而易见。例如，它有一个硬编码的最大接收缓冲区为2MiB（与TCP缓冲区分开），这极大地限制了高带宽延迟积链路上的传输速度（即使是快速的本地链路，比如作者拥有的10Gbps链路）。加密也可能成为瓶颈。hpn-ssh[1]旨在解决这个问题，但我不太确定在重要系统上运行一个SSH分支是否合适。1. https://github.com/rapier1/hpn-ssh

comments.author: nh2
comments.content:
> has a hardcoded maximum receive buffer of 2MiBFor completeness, I want to add:The 2MiB are per SSH "channel" -- the SSH protocol multiplexes multiple independent transmission channels over TCP [1], and each one has its own window size.rsync and `cat | ssh | cat` only use a single channel, so if their counterparty is an OpenSSH sshd server, their throughput is limited by  the 2MiB window limit.rclone seems to be able to use multiple ssh channels over a single connection; I believe this is what the `--sftp-concurrency` setting controls.Some more discussion about the 2MiB limit and links to work for upstreaming a removal of these limits can be found in my post [3].Looking into it just now, I found that the SSH protocol itself already supports dynamically growing per-channel window sizes with `CHANNEL_WINDOW_ADJUST`, and OpenSSH seems to generally implement that. I don't fully grasp why it doesn't just use that to extend as needed.I also found that there's an official `no-flow-control` extension with the description> channel behaves as if all window sizes are infinite.
>
> This extension is intended for, but not limited to, use by file transfer applications that are only going to use one channel and for which the flow control provided by SSH is an impediment, rather than a feature.So this looks exactly as designed for rsync. But no software implements this extension!I wrote those things down in [4].It is frustrating to me that we're only a ~200 line patch away from "unlimited" instead of shitty SSH transfer speeds -- for >20 years![1]: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4254#section-5[2]: https://rclone.org/sftp/#sftp-concurrency[3]: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=40856136[4]: https://github.com/djmdjm/openssh-portable-wip/pull/4#issuec...
comments.content_cn: 有一个硬编码的最大接收缓冲区限制为2MiB。为了完整起见，我想补充说明：这2MiB是针对每个SSH“通道”的——SSH协议通过TCP复用多个独立的传输通道[1]，每个通道都有自己的窗口大小。rsync和`cat | ssh | cat`只使用单个通道，因此如果它们的对端是OpenSSH sshd服务器，其吞吐量会受到2MiB窗口限制的制约。rclone似乎能够在单个连接上使用多个SSH通道；我认为这由`--sftp-concurrency`设置控制。关于2MiB限制的更多讨论以及移除这些限制的上游工作链接可以在我的帖子[3]中找到。刚才研究时，我发现SSH协议本身已经通过`CHANNEL_WINDOW_ADJUST`支持动态增长每个通道的窗口大小，而OpenSSH似乎普遍实现了这一点。我不完全理解为什么它不直接按需使用该机制来扩展窗口。我还发现有一个官方的`no-flow-control`扩展，其描述为：通道的行为就像所有窗口大小都是无限的。该扩展旨在（但不限于）供仅使用一个通道的文件传输应用程序使用，对这些应用而言，SSH提供的流控制是一种阻碍而非功能。因此这看起来正是为rsync设计的。但没有任何软件实现这个扩展！我在[4]中记录了这些内容。令我感到沮丧的是，我们距离“无限制”只差一个约200行的补丁……

comments.author: kbr2000
comments.content: The delta-transfer algorithm [0] is about detecting which chunks of a file differ on source and target [1], and limiting the transfer to those chunks. The savings depend on how and where they differ, and ofcourse there's tradeoffs...You seem to be referring to the selection of candidates of files to transfer (along several possible criteria like modification time, file size or file contents using checksumming) [2]Rsync is great. However for huge filesystems (many files and directories) with relatively less change, you'll need to think about "assisting" it somewhat (by feeding it its candidates obtained in a more efficient way, using --files-from=). For example: in a renderfarm system you would have additions of files, not really updates. Keep a list of frames that have finished rendering (in a cinematic film production this could be eg. 10h/frame), and use it to feed rsync. Otherwise you'll be spending hours for rsync to build its index (both sides) over huge filesystems, instead of transferring relatively few big and new files.In workloads where you have many sync candidates (files) that have a majority of differing chunks, it might be worth rather disabling the delta-transfer algorithm (--whole-file) and saving on the tradeoffs.[0] https://www.andrew.cmu.edu/course/15-749/READINGS/required/c...[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rsync#Determining_which_parts_...[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rsync#Determining_which_files_...
comments.content_cn:
差分传输算法[0]的核心在于检测源文件与目标文件之间存在差异的数据块[1]，并仅传输这些差异块。其节省效果取决于差异的具体情况和位置，当然也存在相应的权衡……您似乎指的是如何选择待传输的文件候选集（可依据多种标准，如修改时间、文件大小或通过校验和比对文件内容）[2]。

Rsync非常出色。但对于文件系统庞大（包含大量文件和目录）且变更相对较少的情况，您可能需要考虑通过某种方式“辅助”它（例如使用--files-from=参数，以更高效的方式提供待传输文件列表）。举例来说：在渲染农场系统中，通常只有新增文件，而较少涉及文件更新。可以维护一份已完成渲染的帧序列列表（在电影制作中，单帧渲染可能耗时长达10小时），并以此作为rsync的输入。否则，rsync将花费数小时在庞大的文件系统上构建索引（包括源端和目标端），而不是直接传输相对较少的大型新文件。

在工作负载中，若存在大量待同步文件且这些文件的大部分数据块都存在差异，则可能值得禁用差分传输算法（使用--whole-file选项），以避免算法开销带来的权衡损耗。

[0] https://www.andrew.cmu.edu/course/15-749/READINGS/required/c...
[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rsync#Determining_which_parts_...

The client downloads the hashes, compares them to what it has then downloads the parts it is missing.With rsync, you upload hashes of what you have, then the source has to do all the hashing work to figure out what to send you. It's slightly more efficient, but If you are supporting even 10s of downloads it's a lot of work for the source.The other option is to send just a diff, which I believe e.g. Google Chrome does. Google invented Courgette and Zucchini which partially decompile binaries then recompile them on the other end to reduce the size of diffs. These only work for exact known previous versions, though.I wonder if the ideas of Courgette and Zucchini can be incorporated into zsync's hashes so that you get the minimal diff, but the flexibility of not having a perfect previous version to work from.
comments.content_cn:
对于这种情况，zsync更为合适。zsync会预先计算所有哈希值，并将其与主文件一同存放在一个文件中。客户端下载这些哈希值，与本地已有内容进行比较，然后仅下载缺失的部分。而使用rsync时，你需要上传本地文件的哈希值，然后源服务器必须完成所有哈希计算工作来确定需要发送哪些内容。这种方式效率稍高，但即使只支持几十次下载，对源服务器来说也是巨大的负担。

另一种选择是仅发送差异部分，据我所知，谷歌Chrome浏览器就采用这种方式。谷歌开发的Courgette和Zucchini技术能够部分反编译二进制文件，然后在接收端重新编译，从而减小差异文件的大小。不过，这些技术仅适用于已知的特定旧版本。

我在想，是否可以将Courgette和Zucchini的理念融入zsync的哈希机制中，这样既能获得最小的差异更新，又无需依赖完全匹配的旧版本，从而获得更大的灵活性。

comments.content: Aspera's FASP [0] is very neat. One drawback to it is that the TCP stuff not being done the traditional way must be done on CPU. Another approach is RDMA [2] used by storage systems like Vast which pushes those order and resend tasks to NICs that support RDMA so that applications can read and write directly to the network instead of to system buffers.0. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_and_Secure_Protocol1. https://docs.weka.io/weka-system-overview/weka-client-and-mo...2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_direct_memory_access
comments.content_cn: Aspera的FASP协议[0]非常出色。它的一个缺点是，非传统TCP处理方式必须在CPU上完成。例如，若出现丢包或乱序传输，Aspera客户端会自行修复，而非依赖TCP协议处理。据我所知，WEKA.io[1]也采用类似方案。另一种方案是RDMA[2]，被Vast等存储系统采用，它将数据排序和重传任务卸载到支持RDMA的网卡上，使得应用程序能直接读写网络数据，无需经过系统缓冲区。

posts.title: Coding assistants are solving the wrong problem
posts.author: jinhkuan
posts.title_cn: 编程助手正在解决错误的问题
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“编程助手是否解决了错误的问题”展开。多数用户认为AI编程工具的实际价值取决于使用者的专业水平。有用户指出，资深开发者能借助AI大幅提升效率，例如快速将脚本改写为高性能语言；也有用户强调，AI无法替代对软件架构的深入理解，否则可能产生低质量代码。讨论中提到，AI在协助产品需求梳理方面表现突出，尤其能弥补产品经理的能力不足。分歧在于对AI适用场景的判断：部分人认为AI正在侵蚀中低端编程工作，但高端工程领域仍依赖人类专家；另一些人则批评相关研究存在偏见，质疑其结论可靠性。共识是AI工具的有效性高度依赖于使用者的专业知识和正确的工作流程。

comments.author: micw
comments.content: For me, AI is an enabler for things you can't do otherwise (or that would take many weeks of learning). But you still need to know how to do things properly in general, otherwise the results are bad.E.g. I'm a software architect and developer for many years. So I know already how to build software but I'm not familiar with every language or framework. AI enabled me to write other kind of software I never learned or had time for. E.g. I recently re-implemented an android widget that has not been updated for a decade by it's original author. Or I fixed a bug in a linux scanner driver. None of these I could have done properly (within an acceptable time frame) without AI. But also none of there I could have done properly without my knowledge and experience, even with AI.Same for daily tasks at work. AI makes me faster here, but also makes me doing more. Implement tests for all edge cases? Sure, always, I saved the time before. More code reviews. More documentation. Better quality in the same (always limited) time.
comments.content_cn:
对我而言，人工智能能实现那些原本无法完成（或需要数周学习才能掌握）的事情。但你仍需具备正确做事的基本能力，否则结果会很糟糕。例如，我从事软件架构和开发工作多年，已掌握软件构建方法，但并非精通所有语言或框架。人工智能让我能够编写从未学过或没时间学习的其他类型软件。比如，我最近重写了一个原作者已十年未更新的安卓小组件，还修复了Linux扫描仪驱动的一个漏洞。若没有人工智能，我无法在可接受的时间内妥善完成这些任务；但若没有我的知识和经验，即便借助人工智能也无法正确处理。

日常工作也是如此。人工智能提升了我的效率，同时也让我承担了更多工作：为所有边界情况编写测试？当然，现在总能做到了，以前我总会节省这部分时间。更多的代码审查、更详尽的文档、在同样有限的时间里实现更高质量的输出。

I did know exactly what to ask of it because the IT business partners who had discovered the flaw had basically written the tasks already. Anyway. AI worked well there.Where AI fails us is when we build new software to improve the business related to solar energy production and sale. It fails us because the tasks are never really well defined. Or even if they are, sometimes developers or engineers come up with a better way to do the business process than what was planned for. AI can write the code, but it doesn't refuse to write the code without first being told why it wouldn't be a better idea to do X first. If we only did code-reviews then we would miss that step.In a perfect organisation your BPM people would do this. In the world I live in there are virtually no BPM people, and those who know the processes are too busy to really deal with improving them. Hell... sometimes their processes are changed and they don't realize until their results are measurably better than they used to be. So I think it depends a lot on the situation. If you've got people breaking up processes, improving them and then decribing each little bit in decent detail. comments.author: adithyassekhar
comments.content: It's not just about elegance.I'm going to give an example of a software with multiple processes.Humans can imagine scenarios where a process can break. Claude can also do it, but only when the breakage happens from inside the process and if you specify it. It can not identify future issues from a separate process unless you specifically describe that external process, the fact that it could interact with our original process and the ways in which it can interact.Identifying these are the skills of a developer, you could say you can document all these cases and let the agent do the coding. But here's the kicker, you only get to know these issues once you started coding them by hand. You go through the variables and function calls and suddenly remember a process elsewhere changes or depends on these values.Unit tests could catch them in a decently architected system,  but those tests needs to be defined by the one coding it. Also if the architect himself is using AI, because why not, it's doomed from the start.
comments.content_cn:
这不仅仅是优雅与否的问题。让我以多进程软件为例说明：人类能够设想进程可能崩溃的场景。Claude虽然也能做到，但仅限于进程内部发生的崩溃，且需要明确指定。它无法识别来自独立进程的未来问题，除非你详细描述那个外部进程、它可能与原进程产生交互的事实以及具体的交互方式。

识别这些正是开发者的核心能力。你或许会说可以文档化所有情况，然后让智能体编码。但关键在于，只有当你亲手编写代码时才会发现这些问题——在梳理变量和函数调用的过程中，突然想起其他进程会修改或依赖这些值。

在架构良好的系统中，单元测试或许能捕捉这类问题，但测试用例仍需编码者亲自定义。更致命的是，如果架构师本人也依赖人工智能（毕竟这很常见），那么整个系统从起点就注定失败。

comments.author: bonesss
comments.content: Talking and typing feels far more productive that staring and thinking, and there is a cumulative effect of those breaks to check Reddit while something is generating.Humans are notoriously bad at estimating time use with different subjective experiences and show excessive weighting of the tail ends of experiences and perceived repetitious tasks.  Making something psychologically more comforting and active, particularly if you can activate speech, will distort people’s sense of time meaningfully.The current hype around LLMs is making me think about misapplied ORMs in medium scale projects...  The tool is chosen early to save hours of boring typing and a certain kind of boring maintenance, but deep into the project what do we see? Over and over days are spontaneously being lost to incidental complexity and arbitrary tool constraints.  And with the schedule slipping it’s too much work to address the root issue so band-aides get put on band-aides, and we start seeing weeks slip down the drain.Subjective time accounting and excessive aversion to specific conceptual tasks creates premature optimizations whose effects become omnipresent over time. All the devs in the room agreed they want to avoid some work day 1, but the accounting shows a big time commitment resulting from that immediate desire. Feelings aren’t stopwatches.[Not hating on ORMs, just misusing tools for weeks to save a couple hours - every day ain’t Saturday - right tool for the job.]
comments.content_cn:
边交谈边打字远比盯着屏幕思考更高效，而且在内容生成过程中刷Reddit的碎片化休息会产生累积效应。人类 notoriously 不擅长估算不同主观体验下的时间消耗，往往过度关注体验的收尾阶段和重复性任务。让某项工作从心理上变得更轻松主动——尤其是能调动语言表达时——会显著扭曲人们对时间的感知。

当前对LLM的热潮让我想起中型项目中ORM被误用的情形……为了节省枯燥的编码时间和特定维护工作，人们过早选定了工具，但项目深入后我们看到什么？日复一日的时间都消耗在意外复杂性和工具限制中。随着进度延误，解决根本问题变得工程浩大，于是不断打补丁，眼看着数周时间付诸东流。

主观的时间估算和对特定概念任务的过度排斥，会导致过早优化，其影响随时间推移无处不在。所有开发者都认同想从第一天就规避某些工作，但实际统计显示这种即时欲望反而导致更巨大的时间投入。感觉终究不是秒表。

[并非否定ORM，只是反对为节省几小时而误用工具数周——毕竟不是每天都是周末——合适的工作需要合适的工具。]

comments.content: So, your point is that programmers identify the unexpected edge cases through the act of taking their time writing the code by hand. From my experience, it takes a proficient developer to actually plan their code around future issues from separate processes.I think that it's mistaken to think that reasoning while writing the code is at all a good way to truly understand what your code is doing. (Without implying that you shouldn't write it by hand or reason about it.) You need to debug and test it thoroughly either way, and basically be as sceptical of your own output as you'd be of any other person's output.Thinking that writing the code makes you understand it better can cause more issues than thinking that even if you write the code, you don't really know what it's doing. You are merely typing out the code based on what you think it should be doing, and reasoning against that hypothesis. Of course, you can be better or worse at constructing the correct mental model from the get go, and keep updating it in the right direction while writing the code. But it's a slippery slope, because it can also go the other way around.A lot of bugs that take unreasonably long for junior-mid level engineers to find, seem to happen because: They trust their own mental model of the code too much without verifying it thoroughly, create a hypothesis for the bug in their own head without verifying it thoroughly, then get lost trying to reason about a made up version of whatever is causing the bug only to come to the conclusion that their original hypothesis was completely wrong.
comments.content_cn: 所以你的观点是，程序员通过花时间手写代码来发现那些意料之外的边界情况。根据我的经验，只有熟练的开发者才能真正围绕未来可能来自不同流程的问题来规划代码。我认为，认为在写代码时进行推理是真正理解代码行为的有效方式，这种想法是错误的。（这并不意味着你不应该手写代码或进行推理。）无论如何，你都需要彻底调试和测试代码，基本上要对自己的输出持怀疑态度，就像对待其他人的输出一样。认为写代码能让你更好地理解它，可能比认为即使写了代码也不真正了解其行为带来更多问题。你只是根据你认为代码应该做什么来键入代码，并针对这个假设进行推理。当然，你可能从一开始就或多或少地构建了正确的思维模型，并在写代码时朝着正确的方向不断更新它。但这很危险，因为情况也可能相反。许多初级到中级工程师花费不合理长时间才能找到的bug，似乎是因为：他们过于信任自己对代码的思维模型而没有彻底验证，在脑海中为bug创建了一个假设而没有彻底验证，然后迷失在试图推理一个虚构的导致bug的版本中……

posts.title: Archive.today is directing a DDoS attack against my blog?
posts.author: gyrovague-com
posts.title_cn: "Archive.today 正在对我的博客发起 DDoS 攻击？"
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Archive.today是否对某博客发起DDoS攻击展开。核心争议在于攻击行为的性质及背后复杂的网络冲突。有人认为DDoS行为明显不道德且无必要，并指出博客内容可能片面省略了前期交涉过程。也有用户指出事件涉及多重复杂因素，包括网络伪装、人肉搜索、心理操作乃至国际黑客活动，整体氛围类似信息战。讨论中提到Archive.today与Cloudflare因EDNS问题存在长期纠纷，这可能涉及隐私隐忧。部分用户从技术角度建议采用Cloudflare防护或设置严格CORS策略应对攻击。尽管事件背景错综复杂，社区普遍认同DDoS本身具有不正当性，但对于冲突根源、各方责任及事件全貌仍存在明显分歧。

comments.content_cn: 但这里并非如此。具体代码为：fetch("https://gyrovague.com/?s="+Math.random().toString(36).substring(2,3+Math.random()*8),{ referrerPolicy:"no-referrer",mode:"no-cors" }); "no-cors"意味着请求不会进行预检，但JavaScript也将被禁止访问响应体。不过响应体在此并不重要——攻击只需确保请求被发送即可。但更关键的是，只要请求符合"简单请求"的要求，CORS就不会对其进行预检。GET请求只要不发送非CORS安全列表标头，就符合简单请求的条件；由于发送的标头由攻击者控制，我们可以默认满足此条件。对于非预检请求，CORS的"允许JavaScript执行"权限仅由实际请求的响应标头决定。 由于GET请求具有幂等性，浏览器默认发送该请求是安全的。CORS可能/将会被用于禁止JavaScript访问响应内容。 这种机制的存在本质上是因为存在无数其他方式可以发起相同请求。例如，在文档中插入标签实际上会产生相同的请求，而浏览器无法禁止此类请求，至少这样的禁令将对浏览器造成巨大的破坏性改变。

posts.author: rbanffy
posts.title_cn: 中国探月工程：目标2030年实现登月
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕中国计划2030年载人登月的新闻展开，核心话题是新一轮“太空竞赛”的意义与中美竞争态势。有人认为此次竞赛与冷战时期不同，中国拥有更稳定的经济基础，即使落后也不会轻易放弃太空计划；也有用户指出，历史上的太空竞赛本质是地缘政治博弈，技术只是副产品。讨论中提到，部分人质疑载人登月的必要性，认为机器人可能更高效廉价，同时有用户提及在台湾地区曾遇到对阿波罗登月真实性的怀疑观点。对于竞赛结果，有观点认为美国虽计划更宏大但执行脆弱，中国则稳步推进；不少用户对竞赛持积极态度，认为竞争能推动工程技术创新，甚至希望美国若落后能借此激发变革。共识在于，多数认同新一轮竞赛已形成，且可能持续较长时间，但关于载人任务的价值、竞赛驱动因素及中美技术路径的可靠性仍存在分歧。

comments.author: hdivider

It's likely to be much longer term and grander in scale over time, as we compete for the best spots on the Moon and the first human landing on Mars in the decades to come.

comments.author: jmyeet
comments.content: Some people seem to think the previous space race was about technology. That was all incidental. The Space Race was entirely geopolitical. It was a conflict proxy, an artifact of the Cold War. Any technology was entirely incidental.The US has been talking about a return to the Moon for 50 years. George W Bush talked about it in 2004. It still hasn't happened. Artemis is limping along but it's entirely pork barrelling for the overly expensive SLS program that really no future.Some might say SpaceX will come to the rescue. That's... doubtful. Notably, Elon calls the Moon "a distraction" [1]. Why would he do this? It's free money from the government.The answer is actually pretty simple: Tsarship simply isn't designed for this mission type. Landing a Starship on the MOon is much more complex than, say, the LEM for the Apollo missions or the proposed Chinese lunar lander. If you could, your astronats would be 40 meters off the ground. The big advantage of a "traditional" lunar lander is it can't really topple over. Plus the Apollo LEM also had a very simple engine that could only ever be used once but the big advantage was that it was extremely difficult to fail.If you exclude all that, Starship is behind schedule and still requires developing technology that they haven't even begun to test, most notably in-orbit refueling.So why is China doing all this? I suspect it's mainly to develop their own reusable rocket program with a side of national pride. China is very concerned with their national security interests. Being able to launch things cheaply is a critical national security interest.Still, the mission architecture of China's mission (from what I've read) is still fairly complex, requiring two vehicles to rendezvous in lunar orbit. That's also why I think the primary goal is orbital launch capacity.[1]: https://x.com/elonmusk/status/1875023335891026324

美国谈论重返月球已经50年了。乔治·W·布什在2004年就提过此事。至今仍未实现。阿尔忒弥斯计划步履蹒跚，本质上只是为过度昂贵的SLS项目输送利益，而该项目实际上没有未来。

有人可能会说SpaceX会来救场。这……值得怀疑。值得注意的是，埃隆·马斯克称月球是“一种干扰”[1]。他为何这么说？这明明是来自政府的免费资金。

答案其实很简单：星舰根本就不是为这类任务设计的。让星舰在月球着陆比阿波罗任务的登月舱或中国提出的月球着陆器要复杂得多。即便能做到，宇航员也将位于距地面40米的高度。传统月球着陆器的一大优势是它几乎不可能倾覆。此外，阿波罗登月舱的发动机非常简单，只能使用一次，但最大优点是极难出现故障。

排除这些因素，星舰已经延期，仍需开发甚至尚未开始测试的技术，最突出的是在轨加注燃料。

那么中国为何全力推进这些计划？我推测主要是为了发展可重复使用火箭项目，同时兼顾民族自豪感。中国非常注重……

> 争夺最佳位置
《外层空间条约》根本没有"先到先得"的规定。后来者完全可以在邻近区域落脚。实际上该条约鼓励联合科学观测，这意味着各方完全可以在相邻区域建设设施。

所谓"最佳位置"的叙事，本质是美国试图通过《阿尔忒弥斯协定》（并非国际法或习惯法）植入安全区条款来实现土地抢占——即通过排他性进行圈地：如果美国先建设，别国就不能在附近建设，以免影响美国安全。但现实是，非签约国没有义务遵守该协定。中国的"阿尔忒弥斯计划"即国际月球科研站，目前尚未在条款中设置安全区，但最终很可能也会推动制定某种冲突规避机制。

posts.title: UK government launches fuel forecourt price API
posts.author: Technolithic
posts.title_cn: 英国政府推出加油站价格API
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕英国政府推出的加油站燃油价格API展开。核心话题是这一政府举措如何促进油价透明度及其实际应用价值。多数用户认为公开价格数据有利于消费者比价，是自由市场中的重要进步，并希望未来能推广至电动汽车充电站。

讨论中，有用户指出现有API数据尚不完整，需到2026年才强制要求加油站30分钟内更新价格，目前部分数据缺失。也有用户提到已有第三方应用（如PetrolPrices）提供更完善的油价数据库，质疑政府API的即时实用性。在消费者行为方面，部分用户认为专程寻找低价加油站往往得不偿失，需计算时间与额外油耗成本；但赞同价格信息有助于日常路线规划。另有观点指出，部分消费者对低价燃油存在质量疑虑，导致购买决策并不完全理性。讨论中还展示了用户利用该API开发的实时油价地图工具，体现了数据的创新应用潜力。

All these stations are about equally busy so it is not like the expensive one is faster. The less expensive one even has a way better convenience store.This is one of the higher gas price states and people are constantly complaining about how much it costs to fill up, and when I ask complainers about where they buy gas it is often the expensive stations.Many of them think that if they don't buy at the expensive station it will be bad for their car. Different brands add different detergents and additives that fight clogging and build up of deposits in your engine and fuel system.However in 1995 the US got a federal standard that all gas has to meet, and then in 2004 several major car makers developed a standard they called "Top Tier" which is about 20 times more effective than the federal standard. Most major gas brands now sell only gas that is certified to meet the Top Tier standard.Most testing has found that going for something beyond Top Tier doesn't really have a significant benefit for most people. For nearly everyone the best approach is:(1) Avoid gas that is not at least Top Tier. Generally the only places that sell gas that isn't at least Top Tier are grocery store brands and maybe some convenience store brands. The savings with those brands is usually only a couple or so cents a gallon compared to the least expensive Top Tier brands (ARCO, Costco) and your car will perform better (including improved mpg) and need less maintenance.(2) Buy the least expensive Top Tier or above gas that is convenient. You aren't going to notice any difference in performance or maintenance if you pay extra for some brand's particular proprietary blend.

短距离内的油价差异有多大？在美国，汽油价格的短距离波动简直离谱。我曾见过这样的情况：一个加油站的油价是每加仑3.50美元，而在同一条主干道上仅30秒车程外的另一个加油站，价格却是每加仑4.30美元。这两个加油站几乎总是存在如此巨大的价差。这种短距离内的大幅价格差异在全国范围内都很常见。

然而令人惊讶的是，即使许多人都清楚这两个加油站的存在（以及其他价格始终处于中间水平、距离也相近的加油站），仍有大量人会选择价格更高的那一家。城镇的布局和交通模式并没有使高价加油站更便利或更容易找到。所有这些加油站的繁忙程度都差不多，所以高价加油站也并非更快。价格较低的加油站甚至还有一家好得多的便利店。

这是一个汽油价格较高的州，人们经常抱怨加油费用太高。当我询问抱怨者他们在哪里加油时，答案往往是那些高价加油站。许多人认为，如果不去高价加油站加油，会对他们的汽车造成损害。不同品牌的汽油添加了不同的清洁剂和添加剂，以防止发动机和燃油系统堵塞和积碳。

posts.title: Deno Sandbox
posts.author: johnspurlock
posts.title_cn: Deno 沙箱
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Deno Sandbox这一产品展开，核心话题是其在安全沙盒环境中处理API密钥等敏感数据的新机制。讨论中提到，该产品通过占位符方式动态注入密钥，旨在防止恶意代码窃取，这一设计被部分用户认为巧妙。

社区观点呈现分歧。有人认为这种机制能有效提升安全性，特别是对于运行LLM生成代码的平台场景；也有用户指出潜在问题，如该机制可能破坏需要对密钥进行运算的认证流程（如OAuth签名、JWT等），或影响HTTP语义。同时，用户对市场众多沙盒产品（如Modal、Fly、Cloudflare等）的实际选用经验表示关注。

共识方面，用户普遍认可该产品支持多语言SDK（如Python）的实用性。主要争议点集中于其安全模型的具体实现是否可靠，以及是否有本地部署版本的计划。此外，有用户对其运行在云端而非本地的前提条件表示最初不够明确。

comments.author: simonw
comments.content:
Note that you don't need to use Deno or JavaScript at all to use this product. Here's their Python client SDK: https://pypi.org/project/deno-sandbox/  from deno_sandbox import DenoDeploy
  
  sdk = DenoDeploy()
  
  with sdk.sandbox.create() as sb:
      # Run a shell command
      process = sb.spawn("echo", args=["Hello from the sandbox!"])
      process.wait()
  
      # Write and read files
      sb.fs.write_text_file("/tmp/example.txt", "Hello, World!")
      content = sb.fs.read_text_file("/tmp/example.txt")
      print(content)

Looks like the API protocol itself uses websockets: https://tools.simonwillison.net/zip-wheel-explorer?package=d...
comments.content_cn:

      # 运行一个shell命令
      process = sb.spawn("echo", args=["来自沙盒的问候！"])
      process.wait()
  
      # 写入和读取文件
      sb.fs.write_text_file("/tmp/example.txt", "你好，世界！")

comments.author: johnspurlock

That code frequently calls LLMs itself, which means it needs API keys and network access.This isn’t the traditional “run untrusted plugins” problem. It’s deeper: LLM-generated code, calling external APIs with real credentials, without human review. Sandboxing the compute isn’t enough. You need to control network egress and protect secrets from exfiltration.Deno Sandbox provides both. And when the code is ready, you can deploy it directly to Deno Deploy without rebuilding."
comments.content_cn: 过去一年，我们观察到Deno Deploy用户构建的应用类型发生了转变：越来越多平台允许用户通过大语言模型生成代码，这些代码无需审核即可立即运行。此类代码常会自行调用大语言模型接口，这意味着需要API密钥和网络访问权限。这已超越传统的“运行不可信插件”问题范畴，其核心在于：由大语言模型生成的代码，在未经人工审核的情况下，使用真实凭证调用外部API。仅靠计算沙盒隔离已不足够，必须同时控制网络出口并防止密钥外泄。Deno沙箱系统完整提供了这两层防护。当代码准备就绪时，您无需重新构建即可直接部署至Deno Deploy平台。

>  It doesn't prevent bad code from USING those secrets to do nasty things, but it does at least make it impossible for them to steal the secret permanently.Agreed, and this points to two deeper issues:
1. Fine-grained data access (e.g., sandboxed code can only issue SQL queries scoped to particular tenants)
2. Policy enforced on data (e.g., sandboxed code shouldn't be able to send PII even to APIs it has access to)Object-capabilities can help directly with both #1 and #2.I've been working on this problem -- happy to discuss if anyone is interested in the approach.
comments.content_cn:
它并不能阻止恶意代码利用这些密钥做坏事，但至少能确保它们无法永久窃取密钥。同意，这指向两个更深层的问题：
1. 细粒度数据访问（例如沙盒代码只能执行特定租户范围内的SQL查询）
2. 数据执行策略（例如沙盒代码即使能访问API也不应发送个人身份信息）
对象能力机制可以直接帮助解决上述两个问题。我一直在研究这个问题——如果有人对这个方法感兴趣，很乐意进行讨论。

comments.author: falcor84

I would suggest starting with nothing beyond the single AI provider you're using, and only add additional domains if you are certain you trust them and can't do without them.[0] https://simonwillison.net/2025/Jun/16/the-lethal-trifecta/
comments.content_cn: 嗯，这部分确实棘手，但核心观点是：如果你同时处理不可信的输入和私有数据/资源，那么你的智能体就容易受到“致命三重威胁”[0]的影响，因此必须严格限制其访问外部网络的能力。我建议最初只允许访问你正在使用的单一AI服务提供商，仅在你确信某些域名可信且不可或缺时，才逐步添加其他访问权限。[0] https://simonwillison.net/2025/Jun/16/the-lethal-trifecta/

comments.author: _pdp_
comments.content: Very interesting. Might copy it.We recently built our own sandbox environment backed by firecracker and go. It works great.For data residency, i.e. making sure the service is EU bound, there is basically no other way. We can move the service anywhere we can get hardware virtualisation.As for the situation with credentials, our method is to generate CLIs on the fly and expose them to the LLMs and then they can shell script them whichever way they want. The CLIs only contain scoped credentials to our API which handles oauth and other forms of authentication transparently. The agent does not need to know anything about this. All they know is that they can do$ some-skillset search-gmail-messages -q "emails from Adrian"In our own experiments we find that this approach works better and it just makes sense given most of the latest models are trained as coding assistants. They just love bash, so give them the tools.
comments.content_cn:
很有意思。可能会借鉴这个方案。我们最近用Firecracker和Go搭建了自己的沙箱环境，运行效果很好。  
关于数据驻留问题（即确保服务在欧盟境内运行），基本上没有其他选择。只要硬件支持虚拟化，我们可以将服务部署在任何地方。  
针对凭证管理的情况，我们的方法是动态生成命令行工具并开放给大语言模型使用，这样它们就能按需编写shell脚本。这些命令行工具仅包含指向我们API的限定权限凭证，该API会透明处理OAuth等认证流程。智能体无需了解任何细节，它们只需要知道可以执行类似这样的命令：  
`$ some-skillset search-gmail-messages -q "来自Adrian的邮件"`  
在我们的实验中，这种方法效果更好——考虑到最新模型大多以代码助手形式训练，它们天然擅长处理bash命令。既然它们热衷于此，不如直接提供工具。

posts.title: Show HN: Adboost – A browser extension that adds ads to every webpage
posts.author: surprisetalk
posts.title_cn: "Show HN: Adboost – 一款为所有网页添加广告的浏览器扩展"
posts.abstract:
该HackerNews帖子讨论了一款名为AdBoost的浏览器扩展，其核心功能是在所有网页上强制插入广告。社区反应呈现两极分化，部分用户将此视为讽刺广告泛滥的幽默项目，也有用户认真探讨其潜在用途。

讨论中，有人指出这让人联想到早期的付费浏览服务AllAdvantage，该服务曾通过展示广告向用户支付小额费用，但有用户分享了自己因平台提高最低支付门槛而放弃使用的经历。也有用户提出能否通过订阅制去除广告，或将该技术用于企业内部信息推送。部分评论明显带有反讽意味，例如期待自动播放视频广告或弹出窗口支持，另有用户误以为标题指机器学习算法AdaBoost而表示失望。

整体而言，多数用户将此项目视为对当前网络广告生态的戏仿，共识在于认为其实际价值有限，主要引发了关于广告模式、用户隐私与网络体验的讨论。分歧点在于部分用户探讨其技术可行性，而更多人则将其理解为一种社会讽刺。

comments.author: cortesoft
comments.content: This reminds me of a company my best friend’s brother worked for, alladvantage: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AllAdvantageThey paid you to put a little ad banner at the bottom of your screen, and paid you like 5 cents an hour that you had the banner up and you were browsing the web.It tried to watch your browsing to make sure you were actually there, but of course we wrote some script to programmatically visit random web sites. Then they added mouse tracking, so we added mouse movement to our scripts.The most insidious part was that it was also an MLM… you would also get paid for usage by people you referred, too, and then even by people those people referred, with diminishing returns from each level. So like 1 cent an hour for my referrals and .5 cents an hour for their referral referrals.We were broke high school kids, so we put so much time and effort into recruiting people and getting them set up with the auto scripts. By the end we were making in the low 3 figure a month. We knew people who were making even more.Of course, it soon went out of business because of the dotcom bust as well as the ridiculous business model and rampant user fraud, but it was fun while it lasted.
comments.content_cn:
这让我想起我挚友的兄弟曾工作过的一家公司——AllAdvantage。他们付费让你在屏幕底部放置一个小广告条，只要你开着广告条浏览网页，每小时就能赚大约5美分。他们试图监控你的浏览行为以确保你确实在线，但我们当然编写了一些脚本来自动随机访问网站。后来他们增加了鼠标追踪功能，于是我们又在脚本里加入了鼠标移动模拟。

最隐蔽的是它还是个传销模式……你还能从你推荐的人的使用中获得报酬，甚至从被推荐人再推荐的人那里也能分到钱，不过每层收益会递减。比如我推荐的人每小时能让我赚1美分，而他们推荐的人每小时只能让我赚0.5美分。

当时我们是身无分文的高中生，所以花了大量时间和精力招募人员，帮他们安装自动脚本。到最后我们每月能赚到三位数的低档收入。我们还认识赚得更多的人。

当然，由于互联网泡沫破裂，加上荒谬的商业模式和猖獗的用户欺诈，这家公司很快就倒闭了，但那段时光确实很有趣。

posts.title: Bunny Database
posts.author: dabinat
posts.title_cn: Bunny 数据库
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Bunny Database数据库服务展开。核心话题是评估该产品的技术特点、市场定位及与竞争对手的对比。有人认为Bunny与Cloudflare服务高度相似，提供CDN、视频、数据库等，形成直接竞争；也有用户指出其基于libSQL但驱动支持不足，如Python驱动仍处于实验阶段，可能影响使用。讨论中提到用户关注其写入性能是否受SQLite常见限制，以及对比Cloudflare D1的优势。部分用户对Bunny的欧洲背景表示认可，认为这减少了美国政策依赖。争议点集中在产品可靠性上：有用户批评其曾延迟实现S3兼容功能并沟通不佳，这成为放弃使用的关键因素；同时，有用户质疑管理传统数据库的实际难度，认为MySQL或Postgres在Linux上易于部署且性能足够。社区未形成明确共识，但普遍关注技术成熟度与厂商信誉。

comments.author: grugdev42
comments.content: Maybe I'm not the target market for this, but how hard is it REALLY to manage a RDBMS?Any Linux distro can have MySQL or Postgres installed in less than five minutes and works out of the boxEven a single core VPS can handle lots of queries per second (assuming the tables are indexed properly and the queries aren't trash)There are mature open source backup solutions which don't require DB downtime (also available in most package managers)It's trivial to tune a DB using .conf files (there are even scripts that autotune for you!!!)Your VPS provider will allow you to configure encryption at rest, firewall rules, and whole disk snapshots as wellAnd neither MySQL or Postgres ever seem to go down, they're super reliable and stablePlus you have very stable costs each month
comments.content_cn: 或许我不是这款产品的目标用户，但管理一个关系型数据库到底有多难呢？任何Linux发行版都能在五分钟内安装好MySQL或Postgres，并且开箱即用。即便是单核VPS每秒也能处理大量查询（前提是数据表建立了合适索引且查询语句经过优化）。现有成熟的开源备份方案无需数据库停机即可操作（大多数软件包管理器也提供此类工具）。通过.conf文件调整数据库配置非常简单（甚至还有自动调优脚本！！！）。你的VPS供应商通常会支持静态数据加密、防火墙规则配置以及全盘快照功能。MySQL和Postgres几乎从不出故障，它们的可靠性和稳定性极为出色。此外，每月运营成本也保持着高度可预测性。

comments.author: viraptor
comments.content: > Maybe I'm not the target market for this, but how hard is it REALLY to manage a RDBMS?It depends:- do you want multi region presence- do you want snapshot backups- do you want automated replication- do you want transparent failover- do you want load balancing of queries- do you want online schema migrations with millisecond lock time- do you want easy reverts in time- do you want minor versions automatically managed- do you want the auth integrated with a different existing system- do you want...There's a lot that hosted services with extra features can give you. You can do everything on the list yourself of course, but it will take time and unless you already have experience, every point can introduce some failure you're not aware of.

- 你是否需要毫秒级锁定的在线模式迁移

- 你是否需要……

posts.title: Prek: A better, faster, drop-in pre-commit replacement, engineered in Rust
posts.author: fortuitous-frog
posts.title_cn: Prek：一个用Rust构建的更好、更快、即插即用的预提交替代方案
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Rust开发的预提交工具Prek展开，核心话题是Prek作为更快、更兼容的pre-commit替代方案的价值，以及社区对预提交钩子设计本身的争议。多数用户肯定Prek的性能和功能，有人认为其支持monorepo且兼容现有配置很实用，也有用户指出Rust实现带来了速度和自包含优势。讨论中提到，部分用户对预提交钩子持批评态度，认为其设计存在根本缺陷，例如会在rebase时意外运行或与未暂存文件冲突，破坏了提交流程的体验。另有用户建议用后台守护进程替代钩子，以实现无感知的代码检查。尽管存在分歧，但社区普遍认同Prek在速度和兼容性上的改进，同时不少用户仍希望从根本上重新思考代码检查的触发机制。

comments.author: dpc_01234
comments.content: BTW. Pre-commit hooks are the wrong way to go about this stuff.I'm advocating for JJ to build a proper daemon that runs "checks" per change in the background. So you don't run pre-commit checks when committing. They just happen in the background, and when by the time you get to sharing your changes, you get all the things verified for you for each change/commit, effortlessly without you wasting time or needing to do anything special.I have something a bit like that implemented in SelfCI (a minimalistic local-first Unix-philosophy-abiding CI) https://app.radicle.xyz/nodes/radicle.dpc.pw/rad%3Az2tDzYbAX... and it replaced my use of pre-commit hooks entirely. And users already told me that it does feel like commit hooks done right.
comments.content_cn: 顺便说一句，用预提交钩子处理这类事情并不合适。我主张JJ应该开发一个合适的守护进程，在后台针对每个变更自动运行“检查”。这样你提交时就不需要执行预提交检查了。它们会在后台自动完成，等到你要分享变更时，每个变更/提交都已自动完成验证，毫不费力，既节省时间也无需额外操作。我在SelfCI（一个极简、本地优先、遵循Unix哲学的持续集成工具）中实现了类似功能 https://app.radicle.xyz/nodes/radicle.dpc.pw/rad%3Az2tDzYbAX... ，它完全取代了我对预提交钩子的使用。已有用户反馈说这确实像是正确实现的提交钩子。

Give me explicit tooling.If you want to use pre-commit hooks, great! You do you. But don't force them on me, as so many projects do these days.

The results are collated nicely. Just works.Having the default hooks reimplemented in Rust is minor bonus (3rd party hooks won't be any faster) and also using uv as the package manager speeds up hook updates for python hooks.
comments.content_cn: 我是prek的忠实用户，已经将几个项目从pre-commit迁移过来了。对我来说，prek的主要优势在于它支持monorepo/工作区，同时保持与现有pre-commit钩子的兼容性。因此，你可以在根目录下的每个工作区中添加额外的.pre-commit-config.yaml文件，当你提交时，prek会找到并运行所有这些文件。结果会被很好地整理出来，一切运行顺畅。用Rust重新实现默认钩子是一个小优点（第三方钩子不会更快），同时使用uv作为包管理器可以加速Python钩子的更新。

posts.title: GitHub experience various partial-outages/degradations
posts.author: bhouston
posts.title_cn: GitHub 经历多次部分服务中断/性能下降
posts.abstract:
本次HackerNews讨论围绕GitHub近期出现的多次部分服务中断与性能下降事件展开。核心争议点在于服务故障的原因与影响范围。有用户指出，问题源于Azure平台因存储账户ACL变更导致虚拟机扩展操作失效，进而影响了GitHub Actions及自托管运行器；也有用户批评GitHub将责任归咎于“上游供应商”（实为同属微软的Azure），认为这暴露了强制迁移至Azure带来的运维矛盾。讨论中提到，故障不仅导致服务不可用，还造成任务卡顿、计算资源持续消耗等实际损失，部分用户还反映代码下载速度显著下降。

社区观点呈现分歧：一方认为集中化托管平台存在单点故障风险，建议迁移至其他代码托管平台或自建仓库以应对中断；另一方则通过历史对比指出，当前问题虽严重，但相比早期分散式源码管理的混乱仍有进步。共识在于，用户普遍对GitHub稳定性表示担忧，尤其质疑其过度依赖AI运维的可靠性（如用AI处理故障的讽刺性评论）。整体上，讨论揭示了开发者对大型云平台依赖度加深的忧虑，以及对服务透明度和故障响应机制的不满。

posts.title: How does misalignment scale with model intelligence and task complexity?
posts.author: salkahfi
posts.title_cn: "模型智能与任务复杂度如何影响未对齐性的扩展？"
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕AI模型智能水平与任务复杂度对“错位”现象的影响展开。核心话题是探究模型在处理复杂任务时，系统性错位与不连贯性之间的演变关系。  

有人认为，系统性错位（如偏见）相对容易修正，可通过明确提示或规则来缓解；也有用户指出，随着任务变复杂，模型失败更多表现为“不连贯性”而非系统性错位，这在高智能模型中尤为明显。讨论中提到，扩大模型规模虽提升整体准确率，但未必减少复杂任务下的不连贯行为。部分用户结合实践指出，模型常因“过度思考”而自我衍生出破坏工作流的变异输出。  

分歧点在于：一些用户认为最新前沿模型可能已改变文中结论（基于旧模型），需重新验证；另一些则强调问题根源在于用户未能提供足够清晰的目标设定，而详尽规范本身可能比编码更耗时。共识在于，短期可通过控制任务难度、优化提示策略来改善结果，但长期仍需探索更系统的协调机制。

comments.author: jmtulloss

comments.content_cn: 目前的评论似乎都集中在吹毛求疵上，但作为一名致力于利用人工智能帮助人们完成艰巨长期任务的研究者，我认为这篇文章很有价值。它简短扼要，既能在短期内提供可操作的指导（确保每次任务难度适中），又对研究者的长期工作有助益。文章深入浅出地解析了这类模型的运作机制，并融入了业界顶尖专家的见解，同时为我们指出了一个明确的研究方向——具体聚焦于“连贯性”（或者更生动地说，“混乱度”）这一可量化的维度。

comments.author: Soerensen
comments.content: The bias-variance framing here maps well to what I've observed building AI-assisted workflows.In practice, systematic misalignment (bias) is relatively easy to fix - you identify the pattern and add it to your prompt/context. "Always use our internal auth library" works reliably once specified.Variance-dominated failures are a different beast. The same prompt, same context, same model can produce wildly different quality outputs on complex tasks. I've seen this most acutely when asking models to maintain consistency across multi-file changes.The paper's finding that "larger models + harder problems = more variance" explains something I couldn't quite articulate before: why Sonnet sometimes outperforms Opus on specific workflows. The "smarter" model attempts more sophisticated solutions, but the solution space it's exploring has more local minima where it can get stuck.One practical takeaway: decomposing complex tasks into smaller, well-specified subtasks doesn't just help with context limits - it fundamentally changes the bias/variance profile of each inference call. You're trading one high-variance call for multiple lower-variance calls, which tends to be more predictable even if it requires more orchestration overhead.
comments.content_cn:
这里的偏差-方差框架很好地映射了我构建AI辅助工作流程时的观察。在实践中，系统性偏差相对容易修正——你识别出模式并将其添加到提示或上下文中。一旦明确指定“始终使用我们内部的认证库”，它就能可靠运行。

方差主导的失败则是另一回事。相同的提示、相同的上下文、相同的模型在复杂任务上可能产生质量天差地别的输出。当要求模型在多文件修改中保持一致性时，我对此感受尤为深刻。

论文关于“更大模型+更难问题=更高方差”的发现，解释了我之前难以准确描述的现象：为什么在某些特定工作流中Sonnet有时会胜过Opus。更“智能”的模型会尝试更复杂的解决方案，但其探索的解决方案空间存在更多可能陷入的局部最优解。

一个实用启示：将复杂任务分解为更小、定义明确的子任务，不仅有助于处理上下文限制——它从根本上改变了每次推理调用的偏差/方差特性。这是用一次高方差调用换取多次低方差调用，即使需要更多协调开销，结果也往往更具可预测性。

comments.author: gopalv
comments.content: >  Making models larger improves overall accuracy but doesn't reliably reduce incoherence on hard problems.Coherence requires 2 opposing forces to hold coherence in one dimension and at least 3 of them in higher dimensions of quality.My team wrote up a paper titled "If You Want Coherence, Orchestrate a Team of Rivals"[1] because we kept finding that upping the reasoning threshold resulted in less coherence - more experimentation before we hit a dead-end to turn around.So we had a better result from using Haiku (we fail over to Sonnet) over Opus and using a higher reasoning model to decompose tasks rather than perform each one of them.Once a plan is made, the cheaper models do better as they do not double-think their approaches - they fail or they succeed, they are not as tenacious as the higher cost models.We can escalate to higher authority and get out of that mess faster if we fail hard and early.The knowledge of how exactly failure happened seems to be less useful to the higher reasoning model over the action biased models.Splitting up the tactical and strategic sides of the problem, seems to work similarly to how Generals don't hold guns in a war.[1] - https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.14351
comments.content_cn: 扩大模型规模能提升整体准确率，但并不能可靠地减少在难题上的不连贯性。保持连贯性需要两种对立力量在一维层面维持平衡，而在更高维度的质量层面则至少需要三种力量。我们团队撰写了一篇题为《若求连贯，须协调对手团队》[1]的论文，因为我们不断发现提高推理门槛反而导致连贯性下降——往往在陷入死胡同之前进行了更多无谓尝试。因此，我们采用Haiku模型（故障时切换至Sonnet）而非Opus，并运用更高阶的推理模型来分解任务而非直接执行，取得了更好效果。一旦计划制定，成本较低的模型表现更优，因为它们不会反复纠结于方法——要么失败要么成功，不像高成本模型那样固执。如果我们在早期就遭遇明显失败，反而能更快升级到更高层级的决策并摆脱困境。对于高阶推理模型而言，了解失败的具体细节似乎不如偏向行动决策的模型那样有用。将问题的战术层面与战略层面分离，其运作原理类似于战争中将军不亲自持枪作战。[1] - https://arxiv.org/abs/2601.14351

comments.author: bob1029
comments.content: You simply can't have a single shot context with so many simultaneous constraints and expect to make forward progress. This cannot be solved with additional silicon, power or data.Smaller prompts and fewer tools tends to be more stable. I try to stay within 1000 tokens and 10 tools for a single inference pass. I become visibly amused when I read many of the system prompts out there. Anthropomorphism is the biggest anti pattern with these models. It's a very easy and comfortable trap to fall into.The core issue I see with coding agents is that the moment you read a file, you've polluted the context in terms of token coherence. It's probably not critical in most cases, but it's safer to pretend like it is. Recursive/iterative decomposition of the problem is the only thing I've seen so far that can scale arbitrarily. For example, if you invoke a sub agent every time you read a file, you can reduce the impact to the token budget of the caller by orders of magnitude. The callee can return a brief summary or yes/no response to the caller after reading 500kb of source. This applies at each level of recursion and can compound dramatically (exponentially) over just a few nested calls.
comments.content_cn:
在同时存在如此多约束条件的情况下，你根本无法通过单次上下文处理来推动进展。这个问题无法通过增加芯片算力、提升功耗或扩充数据量来解决。更简短的提示和更少的工具使用往往能使系统更稳定。我尽量将单次推理过程的令牌数控制在1000以内，工具使用不超过10个。每当看到那些冗长的系统提示时，我都觉得颇为有趣。拟人化是使用这类模型时最容易陷入的误区，虽然这种模式让人感到自然而舒适。

我认为编程智能体的核心问题在于：当你读取文件时，就已经破坏了令牌连贯性的上下文环境。这在多数情况下或许影响不大，但最稳妥的做法是假设它会造成严重影响。目前我所知的唯一可无限扩展的解决方案，是对问题进行递归/迭代分解。例如，每次读取文件时调用子智能体，就能将调用方的令牌预算影响降低数个数量级。子智能体在读取500KB源代码后，可以向调用方返回简要总结或是否/否的应答。这种机制可在每个递归层级应用，仅需几次嵌套调用就能产生显著（指数级）的复合效果。

comments.author: kalap_ur
comments.content:
Well, this sounds like a "no shit Sherlock" statement:
>>Finding 3: Natural "overthinking" increases incoherence more than reasoning budgets reduce it
We find that when models spontaneously reason longer on a problem (compared to their median), incoherence spikes dramatically. Meanwhile, deliberately increasing reasoning budgets through API settings provides only modest coherence improvements. The natural variation dominates.<<Language models are probabilistic and not deterministic. Therefore incoherence _by definition_ increases as a response becomes lengthier. This is not true for humans, who tend to act/communicate deterministically. If I ask the human, to read a pdf and ask, is there a word of "paperclip" in the pdf? The human deterministically will provide a yes/no answer and no matter how many times we repeat the process, they will provide the same answer consistently (not due to autocorrelation, because this can be done across different humans). LMs will have a probabilistic response - dependent on the training itself: with a very well trained model we can get a 99% probabilistic outcome, which means out of 100 simulations, it will give you 1 time the wrong answer. We have no clue about the "probablistic" component for LMs, however, simulations could be done to research this. Also, I would be very curious about autocorrelation in models. If a human did a task and came to a conclusion "yes", then he will always respond with increasing amount of eyerolling to the same task: "yes".Also, imagine the question: "is the sky blue?" answer1: "Yes." This has 0 incoherence. answer2: "Yes, but sometimes it looks like black, sometimes blue." While this answer seemingly has 0 incoherence, the probability of increased incoherence is larger than 0 given that answer generation itself is probabilistic. Answer generation by humans is not probabilistic.Therefore, probability driven LMs (all LMs today are probability driven) will always exhibit higher incoherence than humans.I wonder if anybody would disagree with the above.

comments.author: FuckButtons
comments.content: So, the hidden mental model that the OP is expressing and failed to elucidate on is that llm’s can be thought of as compressing related concepts into approximately orthogonal subspaces of the vector space that is upper bounded by the superposition of all of their weights. Since training has the effect of compressing knowledge into subspaces, a necessary corollary of that fact is that there are now regions within the vector space that contain nothing very much. Those are the valleys that need to be tunneled through, ie the model needs to activate disparate regions of its knowledge manifold simultaneously, which, seems like it might be difficult to do. I’m not sure if this is a good way of looking at things though, because inference isn’t topology and I’m not sure that abstract reasoning can be reduced down to finding ways to connect concepts that have been learned in isolation.
comments.content_cn: 所以，发帖者隐含但未能阐明的心智模型是：可以将大语言模型视为将相关概念压缩到向量空间中近似正交的子空间，该空间的上界是其所有权重的叠加。由于训练具有将知识压缩到子空间的效果，这一事实必然推论出：向量空间中现在存在某些几乎空无一物的区域。这些就是需要穿越的"山谷"，即模型需要同时激活其知识流形中相距甚远的区域——这似乎可能难以实现。不过我不确定这是否是看待问题的好方法，因为推理并非拓扑学，而且我不确定抽象推理能否简化为寻找连接孤立习得概念的方法。

posts.title: Show HN: Safe-now.live – Ultra-light emergency info site (<10KB)
posts.content: After reading "During Helene, I Just Wanted a Plain Text Website" on Sparkbox (https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46494734) , I built safe-now.live – a text-first emergency info site for USA and Canada. No JavaScript, no images, under 10KB. Pulls live FEMA disasters, NWS alerts, weather, and local resources. This is my first live website ever so looking for critical feedback on the website. Please feel free to look around.https://safe-now.live
posts.author: tinuviel
posts.title_cn: Show HN：Safe-now.live – 超轻量应急信息网站（<10KB）
posts.content_cn: 在阅读了Sparkbox上的《飓风海伦期间，我只想要一个纯文本网站》（https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46494734）后，我创建了safe-now.live——一个面向美国和加拿大的文本优先的紧急信息网站。无JavaScript，无图片，大小在10KB以下。实时获取FEMA灾害信息、NWS警报、天气和本地资源。这是我上线的第一个网站，期待对网站提出关键性反馈。欢迎随意浏览。https://safe-now.live
posts.abstract:
该帖子展示了开发者受一篇关于应急网站需求的文章启发，创建了一个面向美国和加拿大的超轻量级紧急信息网站safe-now.live。网站主打纯文本优先，无JavaScript和图像，体积小于10KB，并整合了实时灾害警报、天气和地方资源信息。开发者作为首次上线项目，公开征求批评反馈。

社区讨论中，用户普遍认可项目的初衷和价值，认为其极简设计在紧急情况下有潜在优势。但主要争议集中在实用性与可靠性上：有人认为网站在移动设备上字体过小，不利于紧急状况下操作；也有用户指出其无法承受HackerNews的流量冲击，质疑其在真实危机中的可用性；还有用户提到数据显示错误（如地区警报错位、温度数据异常）以及GitHub仓库未公开等问题。此外，从可访问性角度，有建议指出HTML表情符号可能影响屏幕阅读器体验。

整体而言，社区肯定项目的创意方向，但普遍认为其需在字体大小、服务器稳定性、数据准确性和代码透明度等方面进行实质性改进，才能真正成为可靠的应急工具。

posts.title: Notepad++ supply chain attack breakdown
posts.author: natebc
posts.title_cn: Notepad++供应链攻击事件剖析
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Notepad++供应链攻击事件展开，核心话题是软件更新机制的安全风险及Windows生态下的软件分发问题。社区普遍认同供应链攻击危害严重，因其利用用户对更新渠道的信任，且具有隐蔽性（如长达六个月的攻击窗口）。多数用户认为Windows缺乏统一可靠的包管理器，导致许多软件（包括开源程序）通过可疑渠道分发，各自为政的更新方式加剧了安全风险。

讨论中观点出现分歧：有人认为应定期更新软件以防漏洞，也有用户指出频繁更新可能增加遭遇供应链攻击的几率，形成两难困境。有用户建议通过winget等包管理器直接安装软件以绕过问题更新器，另有用户提倡在沙箱中运行工具以限制潜在损害。针对攻击者身份，讨论中提到VirusTotal早期扫描记录可能来自台湾用户，引发是否为攻击者的猜测，但随即有观点反驳称攻击者通常不会主动暴露基础设施。此外，部分用户关注实际检测手段，询问恶意软件扫描工具的有效性。

comments.author: Soerensen
comments.content: The WinGUp updater compromise is a textbook example of why update mechanisms are such high-value targets. Attackers get code execution on machines that specifically trust the update channel.What's concerning is the 6-month window. Supply chain attacks are difficult to detect because the malicious code runs with full user permissions from a "trusted" source. Most endpoint protection isn't designed to flag software from a legitimate publisher's update infrastructure.For organizations, this argues for staged rollouts and network monitoring for unexpected outbound connections from common applications. For individuals, package managers with cryptographic verification at least add another barrier - though obviously not bulletproof either.
comments.content_cn: WinGUp更新程序被入侵事件，完美诠释了为何更新机制会成为高价值攻击目标。攻击者能在明确信任该更新渠道的机器上执行代码。令人担忧的是其长达六个月的潜伏窗口。供应链攻击之所以难以察觉，是因为恶意代码以完整用户权限从“可信”来源运行。大多数终端防护系统不会对来自合法发行商更新基础设施的软件发出警报。对企业而言，这说明了分阶段部署更新及监控常见应用程序异常外联的必要性。对个人用户来说，采用加密验证的包管理器至少能增加一道防线——尽管显然也并非万无一失。

comments.author: ziml77
comments.content: I'd say it's more true on Linux that malware can hide anywhere if you allow a sudo prompt (which people have been unfortunately been trained is normal when installing software).Windows enforces driver signing and has a deeper access control system that means a root account doesn't even truly exist. The SYSTEM pseudo-account looks like it should be that, but you can actually set up ACLs that make files untouchable by it. In fact if you check the files in System32, they are only writable by TrustedInstaller. A user's administrative token and SYSTEM have no access those files.But when it comes down to it, I wouldn't trust any system that has had malware on it. At the very least I'd do a complete reinstall. It might even be worth re-flashing the firmware of all components of the system too, but the chances of those also being infected are lower as long as signed firmware is required.

可以说在Linux系统上，如果允许sudo提权（不幸的是，人们已被训练认为安装软件时出现sudo提示是正常的），恶意软件确实可能藏匿在任何地方。Windows系统强制要求驱动程序签名，并拥有更深入的访问控制机制，这意味着真正的root账户甚至并不存在。SYSTEM伪账户看似拥有最高权限，但实际上你可以设置访问控制列表，使其无法访问某些文件。事实上，如果你查看System32目录中的文件，会发现它们仅允许TrustedInstaller进行写入。用户的Administrator权限令牌和SYSTEM账户都无法访问这些文件。

但归根结底，我不会信任任何曾感染过恶意软件的系统。至少我会选择完全重装系统。甚至值得考虑重新刷写系统所有组件的固件，不过只要固件要求签名验证，这些组件被感染的概率就会低得多。

posts.title_cn: AliSQL：阿里巴巴开源的集成向量与DuckDB引擎的MySQL数据库
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕阿里巴巴开源的AliSQL展开，核心话题是其在MySQL基础上集成向量和DuckDB引擎的技术实现与意义。社区观点多元：有人认为这类似于将DuckDB与向量存储紧密集成，可能简化事务数据到数据仓库的流转，减少对Kafka等工具的依赖；也有用户指出其提交历史异常，可能并非为开源而设计，或是内部代码的清理版本。在技术选择上，部分用户好奇为何基于MySQL而非PostgreSQL的扩展机制开发。对于其HTAP（混合事务/分析处理）能力，存在分歧：有观点认为这是有意义的进步，改进了事务处理；但也有用户质疑它只是将两个数据库简单拼接，并未提供新的一致性保证。讨论中还提及了开发背景，有用户担心996文化的影响，也有推测认为阿里因已有大量MySQL代码而选择此路径。总体来看，社区肯定混合数据库的趋势，但对AliSQL的具体实现、开源诚意及实际创新性持有不同看法。

posts.title: Geologists may have solved mystery of Green River's 'uphill' route
posts.author: defrost
posts.title_cn: 地质学家或已解开格林河“逆流而上”之谜
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕地质学家对格林河“逆流而上”现象成因的新解释展开。核心话题是地质构造中的岩石圈滴落现象如何导致河床抬升，形成看似违背重力规律的河道走向。

社区讨论中，多数用户对地质学的宏观时间尺度表现出浓厚兴趣。有人认为地质过程让固态物质呈现出流体般的特性，也有用户形象地比喻山脉的升降如同布丁表面般起伏。讨论中提到约翰·麦克菲的著作和迈伦·库克的YouTube频道被推荐为延伸学习资源。

主要争议点集中在文章配图的选择上，有用户质疑为何使用马龙贝尔斯峰的照片而非格林河或相关峡谷的实景图。此外，一位拥有两个学位的地质学家用户表示此前未接触过岩石圈滴落与造山倾斜相关的理论，这反映出专业领域内对新理论的认知差异。

整体而言，社区对地质学揭示的地球动态过程普遍感到着迷，并在科普资源分享方面形成共识，但对科学传播中视觉材料的准确性存在不同看法。

The continents shifting apart like two opposing currents with the plagues sliding one above another like what happens when two great currents meet... All the solid objects we interact with are like liquids frozen in time and we're actually moving through time extremely rapidly. So rapidly that we are able to temporarily shape the 'liquids' before they eventually disintegrate and melt into a puddle; as also happens to us.Thinking about the world in this way makes everything we do seem much more complex, but at the same time, more futile, than it initially appears.
